An explosive device was placed on the pipeline (about 20m downstream of the previous attack) by a group of anti government protestors. The device was detonated causing a big explosion.  The pipeline was badly ruptured causing about 15000 bbls of oil spillage.  The total estimated cost was 1 million US Dollars for intervention and spill clean-up.

The power supply to a firewater pump was to be switched from a firewater pump generator to an emeregency generator. The switchover operation was to be carried out in a switchboard which also receives power supply from the main platform generator. During this operation an electrician was close to being in contact with live bus bars ( 690 volts ).

While performing a confined space entry on a separator for cleaning ops, the primary air supply used by the worker was cut off.  Need to specify equipment requirements and not rely on contractor to decide.  Ensure personnel in confined space have proper air supply with back up system and a dedicated person is available to monitor the air supply.

A mobile wheeled crane (30T Tadano) tipped over (forward) as the operator was slewing the load to the right, to place it onto a 40ft trailer. The load was pieces of crusher equipment with a weight of 5 tons. The load fell to the ground and the crane's boom struck the trailer's cab. Both the crane and trailer sustained damage. No one was injured.

After finishing drilling a stand at 2354 Meters and reaming down the stand, the RCD (ROTATING CONTROL DEVICE) seal failed, causing an unexpected well pressure, H2S gas release to the atmosphere through the top of the BOP, Reaching almost the crown and placing H2S gas level up to 1.2 % in the atmosphere. Night Drilling Supervisor secured the well.

An explosive device was placed on the pipeline by a group of anti-government protesters.  The device was detonated causing a big explosion near the affected pipeline spot.  As a result the pipeline was badly ruptured causing about 15000 bbls of oil spillage.  Total estimated cost was 1 million US Dollars for intervention and spill cleaning works.

The incident occurred when a 43 year old crew member was assisting with loading a cargo (a reel of subsea cable about 2 metres high) onto the vessel deck. After the cargo landed on the deck he unhooked the cargo belt which was still attached to the crane's load line hook. A sea wave caused the cable reel to unbalance and to roll over his left foot.

A seismic crew worker was walking across a field that was not very steep although it was slippery because of the rain. He lost his balance and rolled down for approximately 12 meters hitting several parts of his body. He suffered leg and back injuries and was taken to a local hospital for medical attention. The accident resulted in 30 days Lost Time.

The labourer was struck by a 0 2" valve when he was opening it for depressurizing a 0 12" pipeline that had been subjected to a hydrostatic test. The valve was joined to the pipeline by a nipple and during the operation it broke off from the nipple hitting the worker. The valve was inadequately connected to the nipple because it was severely corroded.

A fire on an offshore platform was started during pigging operations that did not follow the standard procedure.  The platform was immediately shut down manually and 11 people were evacuated by crew boat.  There were no injuries.  This incident shows the importance of proper training and supervision as well as the need for fail safe engineering design.

During dismantling of a scaffold on an offshore production platform, a scaffolder detached his safety harness lanyard to move under a cable tray. Whilst trying to re-attach the lanyard, the scaffolder lost his balance from a kneeling position and fell approximately 8 metres to the sea. The scaffolder was recovered successfully with only minor bruising.

The temporary electrolyser vessel utilized to produce Sodium Hypochlorite exploded at the Sea Water Treatment Plant, which was previously used as Biocide chemical feed tank. The Dichlor (bleaching power) was added to the tank which had residual water, this lead to a powerfull exothermic reaction and pressurizing the vessel beyond its designed capacity.

While working on a scaffold under the weather deck the deck plate above was suddenly cut by high pressure water.  The potential clash between work operations was not identified in the permit to work, nor was inspection or barriers required.  No personnel were injured.  The situation was caused by insufficient risk evaluation before and during the work.

While dismantling a metal frame shelter, a labourer climbed onto the roof in order to get better purchase on a nut he was undoing. The roof, which was constructed of light weight corrugated sheets, gave way under his weight. He fell 2•À__ metres to the ground, injuring his right ankle and left wrist. He suffered a short period of decreasing consciousness.

During offloading of equipment from vessel to rig, the whip line parted, causing the block to fall from 8-10 mtrs on to the deck of the rig. Nobody was injured in the incident however it was deemed to be a high potential incident  since under different circumstances it could have resulted in a serious injury or even in the worst case a possible fatality.

While pumping cement from a vessel to the rig, the hose line was blocked. The Chief Engineer shut down the compressor and bled off the hose pressure. An Able Seaman was standing in front of the hose when it was being disconnected. Once it was disconnected, cement blew out from the hose connected to the rig toward him. He suffered an irritation to the eye.

A container was being lifted from the platform towards a supply boat. When the container was half way between the platform and the supply boat a piston rod fell from the crane onto a habitat tent. There were no personnel in the tent during the lifting operation and the area was not secured. The weight of the piston rod was 60 kg and it fell down 20 metres.

While a vacuum tanker was reversing at the access ramp to unload oil into the FTC pit of the gathering centre, accidentally its rear wheels reached the edge of the pit and gradually descended into the pit.The half portion of the vacuum tanker went inside the pit, immediately, the driver switched off the Engine and removed the battery terminals of the Tanker.

While crossing the gang way to the material barge for inspection activities, the victim needed to balance himself and hold onto the handrail. Unfortunately, his hand was caught between the handrail and sea fastening I-beam. He sustained injuries to his left fingers and, since the victim has diabetes, it was advised that he be evacuated for further treatment.

During lifting of a Gas Processing Facilities Bridge from the cargo barge, the crane lifted the bridge before the sea fastenings were fully cut, causing the bridge to swing uncontrollably. The bridge hit the welding tunnel and flare boom of the barge, causing minor structural damage to both. The five men who were on the bridge during the free swing were unhurt.

A technician was fixing soundproofing foam inside a vent chimney (confined space) using glue while welding work was performed nearby. Glue vapors were ignited by spark and fire set in the confined space. The technician evacuated via the vent chimney while crew workers were extinguishing the fire. He suffered burns (1st to 3rd degree) on his head, hands and legs.

On the 23th June a chopper Eurocopter Dauphin N2 was about to land on a rig when the pilot felt unusual vibrations. The pilot managed to land the chopper safely and asked all passengers to disembark. As vibrations and noise carried on the pilot shut down the engines. The pilot started the engines again and shut down shortly as noise and vibrations were stronger.

The incident occurred during the transfer of a container from half deck of a barge to its main deck. The container was loaded with water mineral bottles and weighed 6 tonnes.  During the transfer of the container a crane failure caused the container to fall on the deck of the barge. There were no personnel in the vicinity and no damage was caused to the material.

During land rig move,  a diesel tank, 40 tons, partially filled with 30 m3 of diesel , was unloaded with 2 cranes, 40 and 50 tons capacity. When lifting the tank from truck, the load started to swing, movement amplified by liquid inside. The 50t crane was pulled forward and sat on its 2 forward outrigger plated. and tank resting partially on one of the outriggers.

While offloading a 50ft joint of buoyancy marine riser from a supply boat, the upper and lower segments fell to the heli/main deck. The securing straps to the riser body failed. It is believed that these had been damaged prior to the journey. Observations about the condition of the cargo at the supply base had not been passed on to the rig. There were no injuries.

Contractor was injured while conducting a profile survey on a C02 injection well.  Lubricator assembly was being bled down to change tools when a connection failed and the lubricator assembly struck one of the two crew members, knocking him to the ground.  Contractor hospitalized with broken left arm, four teeth knocked out, and deep laceration under chin approx. 6

A hook with load came free from the wire and fell down about 2 metres. The weight of the load is estimated at 600 kg. The load consisted of steel supports for electrical cable trays. The steel supports fell and hit the ground 1.5 m from the 5-6 workers, who were located around and very close to the lifting operation. There was no barrier round the lifting operation.

During a lifting operation on a pipe deck the lifting equipment became caught up in a pipe support. The pipe support became unbalanced. The lifting operation continued without the balanced of the pipe support being corrected. The pipe support fell towards the deck hand and he fell, injuring his shoulder and foot. He was sent to hospital but was not seriously injured.

On the 25th March a Telecomms Technician went to maintain the camera located on the de-aerator Tower, overlooking the Accommodation - Deck Bridge. On arrival the Technician found only the pan & tilt gearboxes present, the camera was missing entirely. The 14 core cable, which has 110V AC power supply on it, was live, hanging down 1 metre with no camera on the end.

Over the year a number of process safety valves (PSVs) are moved considerable distances from one part of an offshore platform to another. The moving is done by people carrying the valves using their hands and arms. This work is strenuous and often leads to various types of injuries. Going up or down stairs and ladders while carrying a valve is a particular challenge.

The boom of the crane dropped 0.5m to land on the crane outrigger because the operator moved the boom -extension from its supports before it was properly connected to the main boom. The operator was standing at the controls under the boom extension and as it fells it struck the operator on his head (hard-hat). The injured person was taken to hospital for examination.

At about 04.50 PM a Commissioning Engineer of a contracting company was standing near by a flexible hose at one of the tank Farm foam pump houses used for flushing water out of the foam lines by using compressed air. During this activity, the pressure hose was suddenly released and hit the victim on his right eye. The injured person was taken to hospital immediately.

On 22nd April at 06:50 AM, while picking up 8 1/2 " B.H.A. the ARC tool had been tailed into the rig floor. The tool was being held in the elevators. In the process of being hoisted, the tool slipped through the elevators, falling and striking the tool joint of the float sub set in the rotary. It then struck the deck, rolled and bounced, striking the IP on left ankle.

A live-line work crew was performing power energization tasks at a 10.4kV transformer. One of the crew members was on a man lift basket installing XS fuses. When installing the second fuse in the main phase a fault occurred, energizing the transformer•À_s surrounding fence. Another crew member was leaning on the fence at that moment and received the electrical discharge.

Thirteen employees presented gastrointestinal symptoms and were given an antibiotic.  The health problem was associated to food poisoning and was considered to be caused by salmonella bacteria.  Precautionary antibiotic was given to other personnel trying to reduce the possibility of occurrence of additional cases.  The bacteria's diffusion media has not been determined.

A 5 kg CO2 extinguisher was under maintenance and was standing upright (with its rusted support) in the workshop. The cylinder fell and its head hit the bench and broke. The sudden gas release (160 bar) caused the cylinder to move at high velocity across the workshop, hit several places and finally came out via an open door. The 2 workers in the workshop were not injured.

Rig rack teeth at bow and stbd legs cracked during jack down operation because the brakes were set (power was not connected). The main contributing factors were poor standards of inspection, inadequate warning system and slow overload response of the jacking system, inappropriate checklist and lack of control, inadequate supervision, identification and evaluation of risk.

A trackhoe operator was focusing on a gate to his left, did not see overhead powerline warning signs on right hand side.  The assigned spotter was not in the vicinity when the trackhoe began moving.  The boom of the trackhoe came into contact with the overhead powerlines, breaking a 7200 volt line.  The operator backed away, secured the area and notified the power company.

A vehicle was hit at back by rear vehicles while going to drop female staff after office hours. There was no obvious injury to any passenger and the driver; however the passengers were taken to the Hospital for evaluation where one employee was admitted for suspicion of whip lash injury of the cervical spine while the rest of the passengers were relieved from the Hospital.

During the connection of an oil flow pipeline (riser) to an oil well christmas tree, a flash occurred which caused the welder to fall into the Maracaibo Lake, dying by asphyxia due to immersion. The crew had tied the riser in the christmas tree and when they proceeded to release it, the riser hit a gas pipeline under pressure, causing a gas release that immediately ignited.

A barge had completed the offloading activity at Bay 2 and required vessel shifting to enable the pipe loading activity at Bays 4 & 5. The port provided 2 harbour tugs to assist the shifting process. The IP was located on board the barge, when suddenly the mooring rope at the bollard nearby snapped and hit the IP's right leg. He sustained a fracture of the tibia-fibula.

During cargo offloading operations at the Well Head Platform (WHP), while securing a load to the hook on the WHP crane block, the block became caught under the frame of an adjacent load on the deck of the supply vessel.  This caused the bottom of the block to swing out from the frame, coming into contact with the person attempting to attach the locking pin into the hook.

On the night of 2nd February 2004, the Production Operator went to bed at 2100 hrs. At 2340 hrs, he was awakened by a strange noise his colleague was making who was sharing the same accommodation with him. He assumed that his roommate was having a nightmare and intended to wake him up. While doing so, he fell from his top bunk as he thought that he was sleeping on lower bunk.

Twenty-two contractors presented gastrointestinal symptoms and were given an antibiotic.  The health problem was associated to food poisoning and was considered to be caused by salmonella bacteria.  Precautionary antibiotic was given to other personnel trying to reduce the possibility of occurrence of additional cases.  The bacteria's diffusion media has not been determined.

During a helicopter approach for landing, an unsecured 4' x 8' sheet of 5/8" plywood weighing 65 lbs was lifted approximately 20' to 25•À_ from a tote tank storage area by rotor wash.  The plywood landed approximately 15•À_ northwest from the original location onto the side of an elevated walkway.  No employees were working in or near the impacted area at the time of the incident.

The plant hot water system associated with the LNG processing plants was upset following the final failure of a valve which had shown intermittent faults for a week. This resulted in the need to shutdown LNG processing trains 1 and 2. During the upset fractionation columns were overfilled, a flare drum was filled with liquids and locking systems were inappropriately overridden.

At 15:30, a contractor worker was preparing to load drill cuttings into a dump truck He was injured by the excavator part on the rear of the dump truck and suffered brain concussion, multiple bilateral rib fractures, bilateral hemophneumothorax, closed fracture of the right shoulder and hepatorrhexis. Possible death of worker. The worker was in excavator operation hazardous zone.

The floorman's left foot slipped from the rotary table and he fell down to the rig floor when the rotary clutch lever was accidentally caught by the driller's long sleeve (coverall) and put it to engage position.  The Floorman was holding the make up tong and his left foot was positioned on the rotary table when it turned accidentally.  The injured person suffered left knee sprain.

During a drill the FRC crew failed to release the off-load hook. The FRC was waterborne without the off-load hook being released in advance and the painter line was also released before the off-load hook. Ships speed was at that moment close to 0 knots, therefore no serious consequence. Potential for a serious incident which could mean the FRC capsizing whilst the ship is underway.

During Pulling Out Of Hole (POOH) 7" Mono-Bore completion joints, the wire rope sling designed to hold one length of tubing joint with a Single Joint Elevator (SJE), was intentionally overloaded, causing the wire rope to part. The SJE assembly fell down on top of the power tong and the parted wire rope hit the shoulder of the power tong operator, resulting in bruises to the shoulder.

While drilling at a depth of 1091 metres and preparing the drilling fluids on the metallic dams, at 1900 a short circuit occurred. A fire broke out on the suction dam, reaching the fluid pumps, electrical control centre and drilling floor. Though no one was hurt, the following equipment was affected: Fluid metallic dam, control equipment, electric control center, fluid pumps 1&2.

Contract employees were in the process of replacing a submersible pump.  Contract technicians did not follow lockout tagout procedures, as a result when the service technicians installed the transformer and turned on the power to check if it was working properly an electrical arc occurred in the vent box with the potential of sending an electrical current to the wellhead by the piping.

A new version of Discos was installed and subsequently a failure occurred in Discos and NAS 0. In  Discos there should be a time delay of 12 minutes for the gas blowdown to flare on each platform. This time delay did not work and the flaring was much higher than the assumption in Discos. Fire pump and deluge was released automatically. No indication of a leakage. There was no mustering.

A rigger was drifting a 3"1/2 completion using a Teflon drift pushed by rig air service at 120 psi; At joint#15, drift was ejected 20 m away, about to hit the rig manager. The rig manager was explaining to the rigger how to reduce and stop the pressure when the drift reached the end of the pipe; a few minutes later, the air hose connector failed and nearly hit 4 riggers in the vicinity.

Survey vendor was carrying out an annual thermographic survey in the low voltage switch room.  While taking a digital image of an energized 400V Motor Control Center (MCC) on the emergency switchboard, they received an electrical shock to their gloved left hand little finger between the knuckle and first joint when they inadvertently touched the chassis of the switchgear main structure.

A heat exchanger suffered a catastrophic failure during the start-up of a production train. The heat exchanger had been hydro-tested following repairs. Draining of the exchanger was less than adequate with residual water remaining in the tubes. At start up the exchanger inlet and outlet were isolated. The residual water flashed into steam, the expansion of which over-pressurised the unit.

During installation of an aboveground water treatment (AWT) vessel while performing permitted hot work a fire started in a drain tank that is connected to the treatment vessel. The fire resulted in an explosion and overpressure of the drain tank. The tank separated from its base and lifted off. There were no injuries. A small grass fire was started which was quickly brought under control.

Diver experienced problems during resurfacing.  He was carrying tools and equipment which were tied to his umbilical but when these slipped downwards he suddenly surfaced upside down with his umbilical pulling his head down.  In subsequent attempts to release him from this position his umbilical was cut partially and he drowned after his bail-out air was used. Resuscitation attempts failed.

An UVCE occurred on a liquid extraction platform located in Lake Maracaibo, when work was being carried out on a heat exchanger of the refrigeration system (propane).  The task consisted of cleaning up the level gauge system of the heat exchanger and due to unknown reasons a propane leak occurred, creating a vapour cloud which drifted to the whole plant and was ignited, presumably a turbine.

After loading out the platform to the barge, a team of contractor workers were assigned to cut the dog plates to clear the grillage system. Upon cutting, the transition piece dropped to the deck and a fire developed which injured 2 personnel. One suffered light burns and the other suffered light burns and broken elbow. The latter was given corrective surgery and granted 11 days medical leave

The fusible loop system surrounding the glycol reboiler was automatically activated. This resulted in an Emergency Shut Down of the Central Processing Platform and activation of the field emergency response plan. Data suggest that a combustion event occurred beneath the vessel insulation and cladding, caused by a build-up of glycol/ hydrocarbon liquid from the still column condensing vapors.

An UVCE occurred on a liquid extraction platform located in Maracaibo Lake, when a work was being carried out on a heat exchanger of the refrigeration system (propane).  The task consisted of cleaning up the level gauge system of the heat exchanger and due to unknown reasons a propane leak occurred, creating a vapour cloud which drifted to the hole plant and was ignited, presumably a turbine.

Two contractors were seriously injured when the pickup truck they were driving left the paved road and rolled down an embankment.  One occupant received cuts and bruises and was transported via ambulance to the hospital where he was treated and released.  The other contractor received fractured ribs, a collapsed lung and was air lifted to the hospital.  The contractor was stable after surgery.

On January 27.01.2007 at 0930 hrs, near one of the gathering centres a contractor team was engaged for a mechanical job to cold cut on a 24 inch Crude line. The spool piece was removed, the line cleaned, multi gas test carried out, T piece positioned, Tech weld applied - but crude vapour ignited causing flash fire. The fire was extinguished by the welding crew. No injury, no loss and no damage.

During the loading of an LNG vessel at berth 2, LNG flowed into the loading surge drum V-3042. The high level trip on the surge drum failed to initiate a shutdown because the shutdown logic had been modified. The modification had been completed to facilitate simultaneous loading from berth 2 and refurbishment work on berth 1. The surge drum overflowed allowing LNG into the Vapour Return Line (VRL).

Three newly rented front loaders were given a task to repair the road. All drivers were instructed on the road conditions & safety precuations. Loaders were accompained to the site by the site forman. While repairing the road the loader's right wheel struck a stone on the road and toppled over. There were no injuries to the loader operator and only small scratches occured to the loader's cabin.

A floorman was attempting to secure a shackle hanging from injection manifold at 7 feet height from the rig floor. He escalated power tong to reach the shackle and rested his left hand on the tong rotary and right hand at the other end of the tong which accidentally rested on the operating part of the tong, injuring his left hand finger. He was taken to the Hospital for further treatment/observation.

A Contractor cable buggy with two laborers aboard, was laying cable along a receiver line when the driver came over the crest of a dune and attempted to follow the line that was laid on the slip face of the dune.  The driver tried to continue along the slip face but the inclination was too steep and the buggy began to slide down the slip face.  The buggy then rolled over twice and eded up on its wheels.

On August 15, 2010, at around 1345 hours, a contractor ambulance rolled over on the access road about 3 km before the well site. Two people were travelling in the vehicle and one of them sustained abrasions and sprain injuries to his right hand and he was referred for assessment to a hospital. After primary care he was discharged and resumed his duty. Investigation team formed and investigation underway.

A 25 ton Mobile Crane was unloading steel pipes from a vehicle which was in a yard that was near to a gathering centre. The load that was being lifted was in excess of the crane's capacity at that perticular working radius. As a result, when the crane lifted the load, it caused the crane to tip. In this incident there were no personnel injuries but it took 3 hours to reposition the crane after the incident.

A technician was bleeding gas from the well head as part of routine activities. This well head is located near the roadside (3 metres away) and the release pressure is about 2000psi. While releasing the gas from the well head, 2 company vehicles arrived and the technician stopped both the vehicles due to this activity. Both vehicles stopped and the technician closed the bleed valve in order to let them pass.

A consulting site supervisor was fatally injured from a perforating gun discharge on a well servicing job. The supervisor was standing in the hazard zone of the perforating gun while it was on the catwalk. The perforating gun operator/blaster did not properly isolate the firing mechanisms and accidentally fired the gun while the site supervisor and perforating helper were standing next to the perforating gun.

During the lifting of the load (Top Drive System (TDS) on dolly track), the TDS started to swing due to the movement of the tender. The injured person suddenly moved towards the load and put his hand on it in an attempt to prevent it from hitting an adjacent electrical bridle. The dolly track shifted towards the TDS and crushed the injured person's fingers between the dolly track lower stop and the TDS frame.

A crew of the contractor company was performing loading and unloading operations at the field well pad using a crane mounted on a truck. At 09:35 the revolving portion of the crane injured a rigger. At 14:00 the casualty was transported to the clinical hospital by sanitary aviation aircraft. The diagnosis: comminuted fractures of upper and lower jaws. Brain concussion. Traumatic shock. Stable grave condition.

After the passenger aircraft had landed and passengers alighted, the crew carried out a routine cabin inspection.  They found that the emergency exit door handle that allows outside air into the plane had been tampered with. A few pieces of paper were found to have been pushed inside the spot for stopping the air.  Investigation revealed that the passenger sitting next to the door had been inserting the paper.

A new turbine-driven water injection pump had been installed and manifolded into the existing pump system. A fire occurred within the existing water injection pump turbine when the newly installed pump was turned on. Water from the new pump system was forced backwards through the old system when a flow safety valve failed. This resulted in flames and smoke being emitted from the existing turbine air inlet duct.

An explosion occurred in the boiler-room.  2 boiler operators had the task of starting the burning process after a major overhaul of the furnace. The expulsion was not performed properly resulting in a gas explosion. The blast threw both operators. The boiler room was partially destroyed. One operator suffered serious injuries and burns and the second employee suffered only bruising. Both were taken to hospital.

Two workers where cut off obsolete support brackets underneath the cantilever  to remove potential of dropped objects. When the plate was nearly cut, the welder instructed this co-worker to hold the steel plate to prevent it from falling onto scaffold platform. The plate slid through his hands, the re-enforcement bracket at the top of the plate cut the right side of his neck (10cm length, 1cm depth estimated).

A contractor crew member was assigned to carry out welding work on a Flow Arm from the header to the cellar pit. As gas leaked from Annulus B- second isolation 2.1/16" Diameter downstream flange, it became ignited, due to contact with the spatters resulting from welding. The fire was immediately extinguished. Nobody received any injury as other personnel working in the cellar pit evacuated the area immediately.

During unplanned inpection of tank, a contractor was overcome by fumes in the ballast tank on a barge storing drill cuttings, 3 co-workers then entered to assist.  Another coworker then disconnected the air hose from the compressor & inserted it into the tank, reviving the victims.  Lack of knowledge of risks of entering a confined space, absence of a safe sytem of work, lack of proper safety equipment for task.

Contract employee was attempting to move a joint of drill pipe by himself by cradeling one end of the pipe in his arms and shifting that end from one rack to the other.  In the process of moving the pipe he slipped in the mud and fell forward with the pipe still cradled in his arms.  When he struck the ground, the pipe fell on top of his arms, breaking the left one.  Contractor was hospitalized for surgery on his arm.

Refrigeration compressor Motor cooler fell off during start up of compressor motor. Cooler was found to have detached from the motor and fallen on the ground floor after tilting from first floor platform. Motor NDE side end cover also had fallen off on the compressor/motor platform. No injury as nobody was there in the vicinity at the time of the incident. Compressor was stopped from Man Turbo compressor control panel.

The Assistant Rig Superintendent (ARS) held on to a valve handle on the manifold whilst passing from the central work platform to the outer work platform. The handle came away from the valve as it was later found to have no retaining pin in place or any other method of securing and the ARS fell 1.16 metres. All non secured valve handles were removed from the manfold and modified so that they could be correctly secured.

The crew had just made a rotary connection and the mud pumps were engaged when the drill bit plugged up and the kelly hose union pulled off from the pipe nipple in the swivel. The safety chain then broke, allowing the end of the kelly hose to fall 80-90 feet towards the rig floor and strike the victim. prevention techniques would be to establish method and time frame criteria for pressure lines and safety cables/chains.

During the commissioning phase of a new FPSO a major hydrocarbon release (estimated at 28,000kg) occurred when the pressure vacuum (PV)  breaker protecting the cargo tanks from over and under pressure released gas to the atmosphere at a pressure lower than the design intent. The hydrocarbon release was detected by the gas detection system and the appropriate actions were initiated, resulting in shutdown of the facility.

An overhead crane, spanning about 20 meters, derailed at the end opposite to the cab while carrying a heavy load. The crane fell to the ground. There was severe material damage to the crane and other equipment in the area. No people were injured, but the incident was classified as a potential fatality. Material analysis has concluded that the failure was caused by fatigue in some of the structural elements of the crane.

The incident occurred while a crew was installing a spade at MOV top flange on a 48" spurline. A second crew had been working simultaneously at another MOV on the same line 1.5 km away, replacing a 48" spacer with a spade. The second maintenance crew opened the flange and this acted as a vacuum/syphon, causing crude oil to gush out of the loosened flange where the first crew was working, flooding and overflowing the pit.

While studying rock outcrops in a riverbed in Assam, India, a geological team had three shots fired at them from an unidentified source.  The team's security personnel returned fire while the rest of the team retreated back to the vehicles.  No injuries were incurred by any memeber of the geological team.  It is believed that one of the insurgency groups that operate in the area fired the shots as a warning to keep away.

A Toyota Hilux double cab pick-up vehicle assigned to Village Socialisation activities was involved in an accident approximately 9km from the well site on 28/11/2014 at approximately 17:45 hrs which resulted in one fatality, a Police Reservist. The vehicle was carrying six persons; one other occupant sustained spinal injuries and required aero-medical evacuation to Nairobi and four other occupants received minor injuries.

Personnel were working, demolishing a temporary dewatering and pig trap facility, when nitrogen at 6 bar pressure was released from an 80mm nozzle on the temporary flowline. At the time of the nitrogen release a person was working in the area carrying out modifications to the deck grating. The person took immediate evasive action to exit the area and no injury was sustained, however the potential existed for asphyxiation.

A marine vessel lifted an 8.2-ton ESD valve onto the cellar deck of an offshore platform.  After the inital lift to the cellar deck, the crane hook repositioned through the top deck so the valve could be moved inboard on a stronger deck location.  While lifting the valve (approx. one foot off deck), the crane wire broke; and the load fell to the deck.  There were no injuries or property damage resulting from this incident.

During implementation of wood-cutting operations by a contractor company a cut tree fell on the cabin of a multi-purpose light-armored towing vehicle as a result of which an operator received an injury of the left forearm and the head. The casualty was rendered first aid, after which he was transported to an injury care station in Turtas settlement. The diagnosis: closed fracture of the left forearm, craniocerebral injury.

During shutdown, one of the tasks to be carried out was to install new plate over the badly corroded deck plate on Module 1, main deck area about five meters away from the incident location. The new plate installation required 3 holes to be cut. Injured person#2 was assigned to do cutting whilst the IP#1 was observing. IP#2 was cutting the final hole and IP was standing in the middle of the plate when the flash fire occured.

At approximately 1:35 am, a fire incident occurred at a production platform offshore. The platform was shutdown and the 3 personnel onboard the platform were safely evacuated without injury. The site emergency response team was immediately activated and with the support of the Company•À_s Emergency Coordination Centre. The fire was extinguished a few hours later. Vessels in the vicinity were mobilised to aid in this response.

RELEASE - GAS LEAK FROM A 10" FLANGE - 10" 900# flange on FGC 2 piping developed a gas leak.  The Actual Consequence of 'Level 3' is due to:  1. Problems isolating the flange to safely perform the gasket replacement (bleed down).  2. We surpassed the 144 hour limit for January which called for us to reduce flaring after 2 continuous hours as per MMS approval.  This caused deferred production which was approximately $346000.

A Cementer was standing on top of the batch mixer to take a sample using a metal bucket tied to a length of rope. The bucket got caught in the agitator and the rope wound around the agitator shaft. This caused the rope to be jerked suddenly from his hands. He managed to release his left hand but the right hand was cut by the rope running across the palm . The doctor had to amputate the right hand ring finger and little finger.

Contractor driver rolled a heavy goods transport while conducting a rig move.  The transport was loaded with a power pack, generator, and container attempted to negotiate a curve in the road at speed not suitable for the load and road conditions resulting in lost control of the transport.  The transport load, which was unsecured, shifted and rolled the truck over.   The driver received lacerations to his hand requiring sutures.

During loading out the platform to the barge, a team of scaffolders were dismantling the scaffolding gangway connecting the embarking tower to the cellar deck, at a height of about 5 metres. As works progressed, the gangway collapsed and swung toward the tower causing 2 scaffolders working on the gangway to fall to the ground. One victim was hospitalised and given 11 days medical leave. The other was given outpatient treatment.

Maintenance was being carried out on the Top Drive System (TDS). The task involved changing the packing on the swivel. The TDS was approx 14 feet above the rig floor. The IP had returned to the work location after going for a drink and was in the process of hooking his safety lanyard to the top drive frame when he fell to the rig floor. He was able to walk to the tool store. Injuries were sustained to his wrists, nose and knee.

A loaded Crude Oil Tanker on its way to deliver the crude oil, rolled over on its right side from a bridge. The front right tyre had burst. The driver lost control of the vehicle and it hit the right side wall of the bridge and rolled over almost 10 -12 feet down the bridge. The driver sustained injuries to his hands and legs. The co-driver escaped unhurt. Approximately 8-10 kl of Oil leaked from the rear bottom side of the tank.

At 17:40, a vehicle driven by a  contractor driver was on an infield road on the way to the well, when a fire broke out in the engine compartment. A fire brigade arrived on the scene and put out the fire. The driver and passenger (supervisor) were not hurt. The vehicle was completely destroyed in the fire. The cause of the fire is being investigated. The vehicle was fitted with safety belts. There was no onboard monitoring system.

At approximately 15:45 hrs a Voyager was moving towards the southwest corner of a platform from a south easterly direction to be in position prior to going in to the platform to work cargo.  The second Mate was on watch.  As the vessel made her approach the second mate turned the controls with the intention of swinging the vessel into a stand off position but this had no effect on the vessel's course. This resulted in a collission.

A painter was commencing Ultra High Pressure (UHP) water blasting operation on Jacking Leg 2 using rope access. He did not use the Kevlar foot cover around his safety boots which was the correct PPE for the job. During blasting, the painter lost his balance and the Ultra High Pressure lance made contact with his right foot. The water jet cut through the painter•À_s safety boot and into his foot. He suffered deep cut to his right foot.

On 24th April, at approximately 12:40 Hrs, during start-up of train 5, while lining-up the production header to train 5, a sudden pressure pulsation (Hydraulic hammer) occurred that caused movement of the inlet header, resulting in displacement of the inlet pipe and damage to pipe supports. Due to rupture of vent and drain lines, gas and approximately 2 bbls of liquid was released. No other damage or personnel injuries were reported.

During the vessel crew change that was taking place in the bay by fast rescue craft (FRC), two separate observations were made of crew members onboard the FRC standing up and not wearing life-vests whilst the FRC was in motion. The vessel bridge was immediately informed on both occasions and told to make sure FRC transfers were being performed with all passengers and crew wearing life-vests and sitting down while the FRC is in motion.

A crude oil leak was reported from one of the flowlines feeding to the gathering centre (GC). The GC attendent drove a vehicle to see the point of leak and the vehicle caught fire immediately due to the explosive atmosphere which had built-up in that area.It resulted in a major fire engulfing two crude oil flow lines and an adjacent disposal pit. The fire was extinguished and the attendant transfered to hospital to treat burn injuries.

Contractor was injured during the unloading of a pumping unit.  The injured employee was on the bed of the winch truck pulling slack on the boom line as the poles were being laid down.  The third (auxiliary) line was not in service but broke at the hook because it was engaged and secured to the tailboard.  The line broke and swung around striking the employee on the right posterior thigh causing a deep laceration and broken femur bone.

The worker was installing a support to prevent land falls in a dig hole for a concrete base construction. Suddenly one of the planks used for the support fell down and caught the left hand of the worker on his wrist. The Emergency Plan was applied immediately. Because of the severity of the injury, the worker was driven to the nearest Hospital looking for specialized care. As a consequence of the incident the worker lost his left hand.

During rigging for spooling, a roller window (153 kg) fell down 5 metres when it was being adjusted into position by fork lift. There was no personal injury or damage to product. 2 operators were involved in the incident, a fork lift driver and an operator assisting the driver. The operator was standing by the staircase at a safe distance, when the incident occurred. The roller window fell to the right as a result of being over weight.

Following the completion of shutdown repair work on a Fractionation reboiler, the unit was being prepared for return to service. While drying process lines, an incorrect line-up allowed LPG to flow to a flare drum which went into high level alarm (25%).  The process line-up was corrected at 60% level, however, the level increased above 80% before stabilising, and consistent with standing instructions production was progressively stopped.

An employee was working on top of the subsea tree installing a lift adaptor when he slipped and fell. There was a lack of suitable tie-off points for his full body harness and he impacted the tree before the lanyard stopped his fall. The job he was performing should have required the use of the rig crane. The particular operation had not been fully discussed in the pre-job meetings and was not adequately detailed in the written procedures.

During underbalanced operations, a combination of landing joint and crossover were made up into the rathole. The crossover-landing joint combination was then lifted with the tongs of the top drive to allow the installation of the top BOP, but the crossover became stuck in the top drive. This was unseen by the crew and when the landing joint was going to be screwed on the hanger ball, the crossover fell and landed on the rig floor operator.

The driving rope of the pulley-block system had already been unwound by the main drum, cut and fastened again with a clip to the drum. The remaining rope, which was laid out on the work platform, and the slide, was rolled up again slowly on the main drum. The drilling workers led the rope. With the last metres the drum made a sudden, fast revolution, so that the casualty was caught by the rope and jammed between the main drum and driving rope.

A Contractor crew was performing preparatory work on the well. At 18:15, after loosening the dog nut, the crew started the BOP installation, with the hanger pulled out to a height of 1 metre, when a crippling of APRS-40 hoist unit lower derrick section occurred at the junction of two sections due to improper wedge locking, which resulted in the tear-out of tubing coupling in the ETA-60 and parting of tubing with cable and ESP. No one was hurt.

While using the lathe in the FPSO workshop, a mechanical technician suffered serious injuries to left and right hands, fingers/thumb and left arm when his arms were pulled into the lathe by the sleeve of his overalls. The IP tried to depress the brake with his foot but it did not depress properly because his toe was caught under the edge of the brake preventing its activation. A co-worker came to his aid and activated the emergency stop button.

2 wire line assistants were retrieving a valve from its container. One personnel was lifting the bottom of the container while the other wireline assistant was waiting in front of container to support the valve with his hand. He placed his hand on the floor grating and when the valve dropped out from the container, his finger tip was caught in between the valve and the grating. He suffered a minor cut and laceration to his right hand finger tip.

During the disassembling phase of the Annular Preventer, the Derrick Services equipment could not release the rubber Packing Unit of the superior cap in spite of having hammered it very insistently with woods. The Derrick supervisor asked to use the crane to put the weight of a Drill Pipe Joint (DP) on the packing unit, and thus be able to release the rubber. The last time the operation was repeated, the hook of the crane opened and the DP fell.

During deployment of a BOP lower Kevlar the strap stretcher on the top section of the buoyancy snapped while passing through housing. With the riser hanging off in the spider the worker started to replace the missing Kevlar strap stretcher for riser buoyancy. Whe he had just started to tighten the cargo strap a couple times with the ratchet spanner, the upper Kevlar strap stretcher also snapped and fell 3.5 metres, weight 3,25 kg and hit his arm.

A fire drill at the shore base included fire department trainers.  The fire fighting demonstration started with a fire blanket, 6 people carried out the drill and the injured person was the seventh. He followed instructions but the wind changed direction and blew the flame towards his body while he tried to cover the fire with a blanket. He sustained second degree burns from the fire and heat to his arms, one hand and to the right side of his face.

A worker at the well site was transferring fluids between the produced water and condensate tanks. In the course of transferring the condensate into the condensate tank, the worker stated he instinctively felt that something was wrong. As he was preparing to shield himself, a blast of condensate knocked him into the transfer truck and soaked him in condensate. He ran down wind (eastward) toward the site entrance to escape the scene and call for aid.

A production crew aligned and connected a pipeline containing diluent which is a substance usually used in oil wells to reduce crude viscosity. The workers were heating the pipe and were trying to fit it into place when a diluent release occurred because of an elbow pipeline rupture. Immediately a fire engulfed the crew, killing the foreman and three contract workers. The ignition source was the welding torch flame they were using to heat the pipeline.

A worker was covered with fuel oil while he was using to clean up a treatment unit. The worker did not remove the clothing immediately to wash the fuel. This action was taken too late and once the patient was taken to the hospital the doctor found second degree skin burns. Causes were: lack or proper directions, equipment and procedures to carry out the cleaning up of this type of units, and proper training for the safe handling of fuels and chemicals.

While conducting a seismic survey in Block 3a, a fire began in the engine room of the M/V Mistral.  The fire spread rapidly on the Mistral, causing the evacuation of all 51 personnel on board.  Another vessel was able to attach a towline to the Mistral.  However, the Mistral sank while undertow.  Oil sheens were seen at various times during the incident, but it appeared that most of the fuel onboard was consumed in the fire.  No injuries were reported.

During pressurization of the gas injector well after replacemenet maintenance of the riser, a gas leak occured in the riser pit. A total of 3 gas detectors were eventually triggered and this resulted in an automatic emergency shutdown of the facilities. The emergency response organization was mobilised and all personell mustered to the lifeboat stations. The remaining gas in the riser was vented to the flare. The situation was normalised after 40 minutes.

A jacket was being lifted from a transportation barge by a DP crane barge. One of the tugger lines snapped, leading to uncontrolled motion of the jacket. The jacket was lowered partailly into the water to dampen its motion. The tugger line was replaced but snapped again. The jacket and crane then made an uncontrolled slew from starboard to port side. The barge developed an 11•À_ list; this was corrected when the jacket was lowered. all the way to the seabed.

During a routine crew change, a fast rescue craft (FRC) collided with a lead. As the pressure on the FRC increased, it was dragged under the lead resulting in the vessel starting to sink and throwing the passengers into the water. The coxswain was trapped temporarily but managed to free himself.  Another FRC was close by and all 6 crew members were picked up safely. All personnel were wearing survival suits with built in buoyancy at the time of the incident.

The incident occurred when contractor personnel were preparing to sand blast a condensate storage tank. The condensate tank was recently identified as requiring coating during a recent turnaround at the Plant. As part of the start up of operations, air was introduced to the sand blast pot and, just after reaching the maximum working pressure of 130 psi, the pot lid failed and travelled approximately 100 m from the location of the pot. There were no injuries.

A new pipe spool was incorrectly aligned and a flange could not become tight.  It was decided to make a correction to the spools and change the gasket.  Pull lifts were fitted to pull the flanges apart.  When the gasket was to be removed the operator stuck his finger between the flanges.  At the same time the pull lifts moved and the operator's finger was nipped.  Investigation showed that this was common to use pull lifts with chains to pull pipe spools apart.

A utility vessel mistakenly ran into a pipeline riser on a remote wellhead platform at 0445 hours while it was still dark.  This resulted in rupturing the riser with a small oil spill and some damage to the vessel.  The vessel had radar and was operating on autopilot.  This incident demonstrates the need for good marine contractor management including adequate orientation and training of the contractor crew in good marine operations and safety rules compliance.

15 minutes into a pressure test during a routine well intervention operation on J16 well, gas was detected by fixed gas detection systems in the wellbay area initiating a general alarm, and the platform was shutdown. The wireline BOP's were closed in but the leak was later found to be coming from the shear-seal BOP. A precautionary downmanning of the installation followed. The emergency closure of the local well control panel was executed which stopped the leak.

Whilst conducting dual operations, pulling out of hole with 9 7/8•À_•À_ pilot BHA on the main (aft) well and preparing to run in hole with 36•À_•À_ BHA on 5 7/8•À_•À_ drill pipe on the aux (fwd) well, a stand of 5 7/8•À_•À_ drill pipe fell across the derrick from the aux well to the main well.  The top of the dropped stand was found leaning against the main well dolly tracks, with the bottom end (pin) sitting not yet screwed (unsecured) in the box of the stand held in the slips.

A vessel conveying five contractor personnel arrived at the platform. The vessel was positioned in preparation to commence transfer of the personnel using a personnel transfer basket. The vessel drifted and her stern funnel collided with the generator and fire engine exhaust manifold, piping and support on the platform. The collision resulted in the pulling off of the exhaust pipe insulator, deformation and misalignment of the exhaust manifold, piping and support.

A helicopter passenger exited the helicopter in the belief that he had been instructed to do so by the co-pilot. The passenger proceeded to walk under the danger zone of the main rotor blades whilst they were turning. No one was injured in this incident but the potential severity is recognised. Poor communication between the helicopter staff and passenger was compunded in this incident by the passenger not following known procedures for helicopter landing and exit.

During a 1st approach of the S76C helicopter to the rig, the crew noticed embedded thunderstorms with visibility of less than 1Nm, final approach aborted, the commander decided to perform a 2nd one, during that one, the craft has been under a severe downdraft at 0.3 Nm and about 300ft, rate of descent was up to 2000ft/mn, the crew recovered at less than 200ft and climbed to cruise level; vibrations were noticed and decision taken to return to base at low power rate

A backdigger transported across a mountainous area on a truck to an exploration well turned over and hit a slope when the truck stopped on a steep bend of the road. To start it again, the backdigger operator used the arm of the machine to push the truck up the hill. During this action, the backdigger fell off the truck platform and hit the slope of the road causing severe injuries to the backdigger operator.  He was taken to the infirmary and then to a city hospital.

The incident happened when the rig was preparing to move from STD location to  the field and the air gap was 19 feet. The crane operator was installing the 2" tow line on the port side. While this was being done the eye came off the bollard due to the twist (the 2 securing ropes snapped) and knocked the IP on his right side (on his hips). He went over the handrail and into the water from a height of 47 feet. The IP swam back to the rig and did not suffer any injury.

While the contractor's bulldozer was collecting sand from a manually excavated site, it failed to stop and hit two labourers of sand crew. One of the labourers sustained multiple fractures and the second labourer escaped with minor injuries. Both labourers received the first Aid at the clinic and then transferred to hospital for further evaluation.  One labourer with multiple fractures was admitted in the hospital for treatment and the second labourer was discharged.

A contractor worker fell asleep when he was driving his car. As a consequence, the car went off the road and fell over a steep slope of a mountainous area. Neither the driver nor the car suffered injuries or damage respectively. However, the incident was classified of a high potential. The accident investigation revealed that the causes and the corresponding corrective actions should be concentrated in supervision and defensive driving training of the contractor personnel.

The rig was being prepared for a move to the next location. After scoping down the top section of the telescopic mast, the rig floor was jacked down using the hydraulic rams (cylinders). The hydraulic rams were then re-positioned for the next step: lowering the mast. Whilst lowering was in progress, with the mast at about 20-40 degrees from vertical, the driller•À_s side cylinder failed and the mast fell down under its own weight and impacted on the ground and substructure.

The incident occurred on an FPSO, during an oily water system operation. Condensate was sent to the hazardous open drain and, via the overflow, to an open, non-hazardous drainage system. Condensates following the non-hazardous drain lines reached the sea by overboard line. At that time hot works that were in progress along the hull lit the condensates. 2 LTIs, 3 FAC, (burns) light material damages, and 36 hrs of production losses. The FPSO was still under start-up condition.

A minor flame was detected on the 8•À_•À_ atmospheric vent stack tip of the New Gas Treatment Platform (NGTP). The flame was extinguished within 2-3 minutes of it being detected through diverting the vent gas to an alternative vent line and purging the vent stack by N2 gas. The incident was due to the cold venting of flammable gas and the presence of pyrophoric material in the vent stack. The cold venting was taking place as the unit incinerator was out of service for maintenance.

A high potential incident occurred on a drilling rig. The Port crane was being utilized to support riser-running activities and as it slewed into the Port riser bay the aircraft warning light fell from the boom tip to the deck (approximately 120•À_). The light landed on the riser bay deck approximately 20•À_ from the two roustabouts working in the bay. The light is approximately 6" to 7" diameter x 5" deep, with an aluminium body and glass cover and weighs approximately 3 pounds.

At about 2130 hours the Terminal Installation Manager, received a call from a platform reporting the tripping of their station due to high pumpline pressure. It was confirmed that there was a back pressure build-up due to valve closure to the crude receiving tanks. The back pressure resulted in the tripping of a number of SPDC flowstations and the rupture of the emulsion process line. The loss of containment escalated when a tank was 'flushed' through the already ruptured line.

Contractor's worker was hospitalized due to injuries to his hands that resulted in 4 finger amputations on his left hand and one finger amputated on his right hand.  The bowl, slips, and tubing were coming out of the hole together.  The injured person placed both hands underneath the bowl while another employee tapped on the bowl.  The tubing above the bowl separated and the tubing string fell back into the well bore trapping the employee's hands between the bowl and the wellhead.

Electricians were working on a Heating Medium Electric Heater to resolve an earth fault.  The pre-population isolation was in place and locked but there was no reference to control circuit, which was live.  Operational demand resulted in the switch trying to make contact.  This gradually degraded the mechanical integrity of the switch against the padlock.  Eventually the switch made contact and heating circuits became live.  An electrician received a shock when checking connections.

Whilst on normal patrol of the facility two operators discovered sparking and a small flame on the heat tracing cable of an unused oil outlet line from the IP separator. The operator attempted to use a dry chemical fire extinguisher to extinguish the sparks but the sparks still continued.  The operator went to turn off the main breaker of the 240V Heat Tracing Distribution Panel and the spark stopped. It took 5 minutes after its discovery to put out the fire.  No platform shut down.

During a barge jacking up operation, the barge experienced grippers failure on leg #8 followed by failure on grippers on legs #5, 6 and 7 respectively. The jacking operation was aborted and the barge towed out of the field. The main contributing factors of the incident occurrence were lack of personnel skill, using defective equipment (2 out of 6 tubes on the upper grippers of leg #8 burst), unavailability of gripper failure warning system and inadequacy of jacking operating procedure.

The accident ocurred during the transfer of a Production Riser from the reel on the aft deck to the tension tower radius controller (chute). The 12 tonne soft strop supporting the head snapped when lifted up to the chute. The initiation head dropped to the deck before continuing over the side of the vessel. No personnel were injured but the riser is seriously damaged. The initiation head that was dropped had a weight of approx. 7 tonnes. It was dropped from a height of approx. 15 metres.

An explosion occurred in a Regeneration gas fired heater. The explosion was the result of a tube rupture within the firebox. The tube failure occurred as a direct result of having no flow through the tubes and the Low/Low flow safeguarding trip being overridden at the time. A detailed investigation determined that a block valve isolation had not been de-isolated due to the failure of the Permit to Work System to manage the de-isolation process after a major shutdown for plant modification.

An explosion occurred in a Regeneration gas fired heater. The explosion was the result of a tube rupture within the firebox. The tube failure occurred as a direct result of having no flow through the tubes and the Low/Low flow safeguarding trip being overridden at the time. Subsequent investigation determined that a block valve isolation had not been de-isolated due to the failure of the Permit to Work System to manage the De-isolation process after a major shutdown for plant modification.

Contractor Water tanker toppled on the right hand side on the storm water channel. The tanker was transferring water from the back wash pit to the Evaporation Pit. In an attempt to avoid a speed breaker on the road, the tanker driver tried to manouevre from the extreme right side of the road hardly six inches away from the storm water channel. Since the tanker was loaded, the loose soil and channel wall gave way, the tanker toppled over on its right hand side on to the storm water channel.

Mild gas leakage was observed from lower side glass level gauge (GLG) of inlet filter coalescer V-590 by shift incharge and area operator during routine plant round. Upon leakage identification level-1 shutdown was activated at 1227 hrs to stop the leakage. All emergency response measures were taken by activating FAT and FFT. GLG was replaced with new one and plant was again brought into flow at 1528 hrs following cold start-up procedures and using the already developed plant start-up TRA.

A contractor crew was performing drilling operations on a profile using a small-size auger-type drilling rig. At 10.30 the rotating shaft of the power transfer caught and reeled a sleeve of safety clothes of drilling rig grade 5 operator (born in 1967). As a result of the incident the crew member suffered an injury to his left arm. The casualty was rendered first aid on location and transported to  hospital. The diagnosis: open fracture of both bones of the left forearm in the middle third.

While the wireline operator and another operator were checking on tool inventory 1.5 meter behind the winch, the wireline assistant (Injured Person) left his designated working place (sitting on winch control seat) and approached the winch from its right side. IP reached his right hand toward the contact point of wireline and its rolling drum. His right hand was caught into the drum causing the middle finger tip (1/2") severed. He pulled out his hand and the glove was stuck inside the drum.

As part of a construction activity on a live plant area, a pre-flush column was being lifted to be located on its foundation. As the column was being lifted into the vertical position (approximately 1 metre from the ground) the crane's rear hoist brake began to slip causing the column to drop. There was only minor damage to the column and no damage to the online process equipment. In slightly different circumstances the incident could have had the potential to cause a major toxic gas release.

A rigging crew comprising of 4 riggers and a crane operator were engaged in moving pipes, weighing between 0.9 and 2.4 tonnes, from a pipe stand to a pipe stack. After a pipe was placed onto the stack it partially collapsed causing the pipes to roll in the direction of the stand some 1.5 metres away. One of the riggers, who was standing between the pipe stand and rack, had his lower leg severely crushed between the concrete base of one of the pipe stand supports and one of the dislodged pipes.

While investigating a high gas alarm on a line of sight detector at an export compressor after cooler, it was found that gas was escaping from the HP flare via an open flange. The PSV had been removed so it could be replaced as part of planned maintenance. On further investigation it was found that the wrong PSV had been isolated. The isolation was corrected and the work party was informed when they returned to site from their break. A formal investigation commenced on site on the following day.

An explosion occurred in an elbow of the oil and gas separation process of a production facility. Hydrogen peroxide was being used for H2S control. The immediate cause was attributed to the explosion of a mixture of hydrogen peroxide that liberated molecular oxygen, which reacted with the hydrocarbons inside the pipe under no flow conditions in a closed sector. The incident caused first and second degree skin burns to the operator. The use of this substance is not recommended in confined vessels.

At 8:00 AM contractor construction crews, and an operator started preparations and the Permitting Process for a hot tap job that was supposed to take place on a 3" water line. When the Contractor Construction Supervisor was informed that the hot tap operation was completed successfully, the Supervisor knew that the "Hot Tap Procedure" had been violated because he had not yet approved the hot tap operation. The Supervisor went to inspect the hot tap and found that it had been placed on the wrong line.

While drilling and making up stands offline, the gear of pipe handler motor, weighing 15 kg, broke and fell down from a height of 104' feet. The acting derrickman, who was working on the monkey board, noticed the gear as it was falling and collided with monkey board.  He shouted to alert the crew working down on the rig floor. The crew moved away to a safer area and the motor gear fell down on the setback area and rolled towards driller's cabin.  No injury to personnel or any other damage was reported.

A jack technician and his assistant were getting a torque reading on each of jacking system as part of a rig recovery operation. While getting the torque reading at the port leg motor, the jack technician placed the torque wrench on the motor and instructed his assistant to disengage the brake pin. Once the brake pin was disengaged, the sturdy force was released causing the jack technician to lose his grip on the torque wrench. The torque wrench then wildly struck the jack technician and broke his left forearm.

In January 2008 a contractor scaffolder, dismantling a scaffold at SVT, was using a single scaffold board as footing from which to create a new working platform. Whilst standing on the single board he found that his lanyard was impeding his actions so he unclipped the lanyard in order to re-position it, contrary to rules. Whilst carrying out this re-positioning, the board upon which he was standing gave way and the IP fell vertically for some 5.5 metres to the concrete ground level, fracturing his ankle and leg.

A mechanical technician working on unit 600 fin fans entered the fan enclosure. He had requested an isolation to carry out a PM, however he was disorientated and entered the wrong fin fan enclosure. An Operator noticed that the Mechanical Technician was in the wrong fan enclosure and informed him. The Mechanical Technician then climbed out and worked on the correct fin fan. Approximately 15 minutes after he left the live fan enclosure the fan was started by an Electrical Technician working on a different permit.

Usually, on the drillship, drill pipe is laid-down, stored and tripped from out of the HPR.  Once the stand is moved from a vertical to horizontal position, the HPR latches each stand in 3 locations to move the stand downward into the storage position.  At the time of the incident only 2 of the 3 engaged.  Whilst the operator tried to correct, the 2 mechanisms released, allowing one end of the pipe to pivot and fall.  The stand skidded out of the HPR and finally rested within 5 feet of where 2 people were working.

Two contractor employees were in the process of cutting the empty metal drum near the welding shop without taking the work permit. When one person started making the holes in the drum with a cutting torch, suddenly the drum exploded, making a huge sound and fire. The top cover of the drum blown off and hit the person who was attempting to make holes in the drum. Fire engulfed both these contractor employees. Other crew members rushed to the spot and extinguished the flames and took the injured persons to Hospital.

A service boat was leaving an off-shore oil field after normal routine work, and whilst en-route to an island,  the Officer of the Watch engaged Auto-Pilot. By the time he realized that the Vessel was in close proximity to a Wellhead Platform, it was too late to avoid the collision. Both Captain & Chief Mate were on the bridge at the time. The Officer of the Watch tried to reverse the engine mode (crash maneuver) but it was too late and the vessel hit the wellheadplatform, causing considerable structural damage.

After back loading large trash bags to Supply Vessel the crane operator on the drilling rig was given the signal from the vessel's Banksman to lift the hook clear of the deck (the hook had a 4 part sling with a tag line attached to it). When the crane hook started to move the Involved Person (IP) realised that his foot was wrapped in the tag line connected to the sling. The IP caught hold of the tag line to keep upright and was lifted 10 - 20 feet above the deck. The IP was immediately lowered to the deck uninjured.

An employee was using an insulated hot stick to determine clearance under a power line.  The employee taped his metal tape measure to the hot stock to determine the exact clearance.  The bot stick came into contact with the power line and current travelled down the metal tape to the employee resulting in his electrocution.  To prevent the accident, the employee should have measured the hot stock to determine its length and then measured the distance from the bottom of the bot stock, which is insulated, to the ground.

Contractors were collecting data from the RSR boxes. They had just finished Line 1 and were in the process of moving to a different location. While riding in a 4-wheeler (Treker), the driver made a wide turn on a non-paved surface, and the Treker flipped on its side. During the rollover, the passenger stuck his hand out of the vehicle apparently to brace himself for the fall, and the Treker's roof landed on his fingers. The passenger's three fingers on his right hand were nearly cut off, as they were barely attached.

The operation was running 13 3/8" casing. As the block was picked up with a joint of casing on single joint elevator, the circulating hose (Connected with a swivel on Weatherford Lafleur Autoseal Circulating Head) was caught with kelly (placed in the rat hole). As the block kept travelling up, the hose and swivel came in tension and the threaded high pressure nipple on the swivel snapped off the hammer union connection.  This caused the hose and swivel to fall onto the rig floor from a height of 30 feet. (No injuries)

While returning a pallet truck back to its storage location the work crew on an FPSO decided to take a shortcut across the deck instead of using the marked, unobstructed pathway. The shortcut included some pipe work over which the workers had to manually lift the pallet truck. During this process the jack suddenly dropped, resulting in the left hand of the victim getting caught between the lever and a bracket. The victim immediately pulled his hand free, which resulted in him severing the tip of his left index finger.

A Scaffolder fell whilst dismantling scaffold: He was working approx 2 m above grade (ground level). The scaffold board on which he was standing suddenly gave way beneath him (it split into two pieces). Although attached by lanyard to the scaffold structure, the scaffolder instinctively reached out to arrest his fall by grabbing hold of a transom (transverse scaffold tube). This resulted in an 'jarring' injury to his left shoulder. He was able to self-right himself, disconnect from the lanyard and step down on to grade.

A forklift operator began to dig up a partially buried tree trunk to remove the obstruction. The pail picked up a 220v energy cable that was located 25cm underground and this produced a rupture to the 220v cable that had been covered by a metal sheath. The cable did not have any warning signs. There was no injury to personnel. The employee had been tasked to dig up trees on the EAST zone of the plant, for which the PTW and HAZID were prepared. This incident occurred on the WEST zone, which the PTW and HAZID did not cover.

Gas from the SWAG injection well flowed back into the water injection system during start up. PSV on WI pig launcher lifted below set point due to malfunction  and gas drained into the hazardous closed drain. This was incorrectly connected to the open drain system.  Basic risk factor: Procedures (inadequate identification of cause of gas release on previous occasions. Gas in WI system not identified during design HAZOPs), Design (Operating design during startup. Hardpipe drain from PSV. Haz & non haz drain connected).

While drilling the 12 1/4" top hole section with flow riser (no BOP) at 220m, the drill started to bounce. Plans were checked for anti-collision and it was concluded there was still a 5m separation. Cautious drilling continued. Some 7 minutes later the well kicked. Mud flowed from the wellbore. Rig crews evacuated the rig floor. The kick lasted 3-5 minutes then stopped by itself. During attempts to pump mud into the well another small kick occurred. The well was eventually filled with mud again and no further flow occurred.

A workover crew was carrying out an intervention to the gas well in order to replace the tubing string. In order to perform the pressure test at of the christmas three, the pumping line between the pump truck and christmas tree check valve had to be tested at 150 bar. When the pressure reached 120 bar, the plug of the check valve 2 1/19 *210 was ejected, hit the pressure release pipe, the superior flange of the pressure release pipe, passed over the safety shield and hit the helmet of the foreman which was at approx. 10m away.

This incident occurred at 11.30 hours but was reported to the Company only at 17.00 hours. A company contracted to construct the accommodation for army personnel allocated to guarding the East access gate had carried out excavation work without a permit to work being in place and without a complementary excavation permit being secured.  The excavation was to a depth of 1.5 metres, no underground service / piping detection was carried out. The excavation exposed a 6" high pressure gas line with an operating pressure of 320 bars.

On the well pad a crew of mechanics  was repairin and cleaning an auger. An electrical mechanic periodically switched on and off the auger power supply from the mud tank control panel. The switching resulted in a short circuit between phases of the breaker and an electric arc, which caused thermal burns of hands of the electrical mechanic. The casualty was rendered first aid, after which he was transported by an ambulance to hospital. The diagnosis: thermal burn of hands of level I-II. Currently he is given out-patient treatment.

Personnel were being transported to field operations via a comercial flight, landing at an official airport. The aircraft touched down 4 metres short of the landing strip, due to strong winds pushing the plane downwards. The landing gear suffered  impact and broke. The airplane started sliding, initially along the runway and then on the surrounding ground, until it crashed against the wall of the facility. Fortunately some personnel only suffered minor injuries.  An official investigation was carried out by the national authorities.

While carrying out a dynamic load test of a lifeboat's release gear, a master link connecting the aft fall wire to the boat•À_s release hook assembly failed. The dynamic weight of the lifeboat was transferred to the forward fall wire overloading it to failure causing the boat to drop over 90 feet into the sea.  The released energy caused the cantilevered deck and davit to bounce violently. The contractor standing on top of the davit operating the winch brake grabbed onto an adjacent section of handrail to keep from falling overboard.

A roughneck was going to grease the top drive and the travelling block. He gave a signal to the winch operator to hoist him up to the travelling block and the top drive by means of a belt. The working height at the top drive is about 3-5 meters above the drillfloor. After completing the greasing operation, the person at the top drive pushed himself outside the top drive. Then the connection between the wire of the manrider-winch and the belt loosened and the person consequently fell down onto the drilling floor, appx. 5 meters below.

When repressurising line a high differential pressure was noted across main isolation valve.  Operators started to equalise pressure using a bypass line around main isolation valve.  After a period of time, they opened main isolation valve.  Unknown to operators a hydrate had formed behind main isolation valve and this resulted in a severe shock to the line when the valve was opened.  This resulted in damage to 150m of the line and its supports.  Operators had not checked that the differential pressure across the valve had equalized.

A 22 year old fitter employed by a sub-contractor to the operating company was bolting up a 12•À_•À_ flange assembly on a new ESD valve. The valve, actuator and piping were unstable and not adequately secured. The assembly suddenly flipped over with the valve actuator striking the injured person on his back, pinning him down to the floor. A crane was required to lift the valve and free the injured person. He broke his back and his leg. The back injury is classified as a Permanent Total Disability (paraplegic: loss of movement in his legs).

Area Operator investigating a seal oil low level alarm on a compressor, discovered seal oil being discharged to grade at the pressure gauges on the discharge of the Seal Oil Pumps. The relief valve on the pump discharge had lifted and it is believed that the vibration generated by the relief flow had caused the pressure gauge bourdon tube to fail. The compressor was tripped, an oil truck was brought to the seal oil tank and the tank refilled, during this period the seal oil level continued to drop, giving rise to a potential gas breakthrough.
