Vehicle one, driven by a company employee and vehicle two were travelling east on a highway.  Vehicle two was almost at a complete stop to make a left turn when vehicle one travelled into the west-bound lane, applied the brakes, and skidded back into the east-bound lane and into the rear of the trailer being pulled by vehicle two.  It is believed that the employee was attempting to pass vehicle two when he realised that vehicle two was turning and lost control of the vehicle when the brakes locked.  The driver died 24.4.93 from severe head injuries.

Supply vessel was positioned with its starboard stern corner towards the rig's forward, starboard column. In this position the supply vessel was allowed to drift away from the rig some 50-100m before being powered back towards the rig (within 10-20m).  The captain of did not notice the very close proximity of the vessel to the rig. The starboard stern of the vessel hit the forward, starboard column of the rig.  The hole created by the impact was 7m wide and 3m high, just above the water line, and also penetrated the chain locker inside the column.

On Sunday 25th October 2009, a purpose built project modular gangway for jacket access from a construction platform parted at the jacket end and fell to the water.  Failure occurred in a vertical pin of a Swivel Unit which caused the modular gangway to separate from the Gimbaled support. This pin failure also caused the Gimbaled support to rotate free of the support bar on the gangway landing platform.  As a result, the fixed end of the modular gangway detached from the Gangway landing platform and fell into the water. No one was injured in the event.

During a planned workover, a Well Control Incident occurred. The well became unbalanced with reservoir pressure during the initial stages of the workover. The completion string was sheared in order to secure the well and control the gas flow from the borehole. The containment of the well was lost after experiencing unexpected gas and pressure at the surface during initial operations and the subsequent kill operations, which were compromised due to multiple equipment failures. The well was continuously lubricated to maintain pressure and bleed off gases.

A standby vessel was tied to the platform's jacket leg due to unavailability of LCT buoy when there was a sudden weather change which initially resulted in vessel navigation mask was touching the platform's staircase. The boat Captain decided to move away from the platform and, in the process of moving off the platform, a few of the boat's handrails parted after they came in contact with the platform's SSB/VHF radio antenna.The platform's staircase grating parted and the jacket legs were scratched. Lack of knowledge was found the basic cause of the incident.

An experienced production operator was performing surface testing to wells with ESP in oil field. He went to a well to start testing. He verified that the foot valve was open, when he was trying to close the gauge valve  he stepped on the corner of the grating floor, which was slightly supported by the cellar wall. The grating came loose and the operator lost control and fell into the cellar. The operator hurt his wrist, knee, head and upper back. He stepped out of the cellar by himself and drove to the medical services where he received first aid assistance.

A fire involving a compressor resulted in US$6,000,000 damage but no injures.  A compressor discharge valve was failing and heated up enough to cause distortion in the valve area.  This resulted in a significant leak.  The gas cloud from the gas leak found an ignition source. There is no evidence of an explosion from the initial start of the fire, indicating that the gas cloud was not extensive.  The compression area ESD was activated after the fire was identified.  Inlet gas to the compressor was shut in. The fire was extinguished by the local fire department.

A hand switch was used to shutdown a stripping gas compressor (SGC) for scheduled maintenance. The SGC was being shut down to execute a planned routine water wash on the SGC export compressor.  Activation of this switch also tripped the lube oil/seal oil supply pumps.  A level valve closed while the level in the seal oil overhead tank (OHT) continued to fall.  Subsequently, a •À_low low•À_ level trip was activated on the OHT which caused a SGC emergency shutdown.  Shutdown valve closed on demand however the package blowdown valve (BDV) failed to open when initiated.

At 07:00hrs on Tuesday 20th December 2005, it was reported that an explosion had occurred at the block valve manifolds at a channel, resulting in a major spill and fire. All production from relevant land areas was shut down. Supply to the refinery was stopped. Over fly was carried out and Joint Investigation Team confirmed sabotage action by unknown persons. Community reported fatalities to Red Cross Organisation (Rivers State), but no confirmation could yet be made. Intelligence reports indicate that communities were chased away by the attackers before the explosion.

In order to get access to the x-mas tree crane the fox-hole was lifted approx 6-7 meters. For the lifting operation a green webbing band sling connected to an air tugger was used. When the fox-hole was lifted approx 6-7 meters the webbing band sling broke, and the fox hole fell down on to it's foundation.  The person who operated the air tugger was hit by the edge of the fox hole on the back of his head. He got a cut above his right knee and broke his right hand littlefinger. The person was later evacuated by helicopter to shore.  The weight of the fox-hole is 5000 lbs.

Toward the end of March 2011, preparations commenced for the replacement and installation of mooring chain on the Riser Turret Mooring (RTM). This work included cleaning marine growth from the RTM by contract divers using a HP water blasting gun. While conducting diving activities at 28m, specifically High Pressure (HP) water blasting for the removal of marine growth from the Riser Turret Mooring (RTM), the protection pipe and tube of the HP water blaster gun fell away. Water jet from the unprotected retro lance struck the diver's left forearm, causing a puncture wound.

During fault finding work on gas lift compressor, two maintenance personnel were injured when a solenoid was activated which allowed start air under pressure to be released through an open pipe. The resultant energy was sufficient to rotate the screwed pipe sections and, during its movement, hit one of the personnel on the face causing severe laceration and possible fracture to his nose. The second one received a blow to his head when his companion was forced backward by the impact of the blow to his face. Both men were taken by ambulance to hospital to receive treatment.

Contractor LWDC - A short service employee (SSE) contract forklift operator was driving to a location to remove an adapter from his forks. The forklift operator was accompanied by a spotter.  A sling hanging from the forks was swinging.  Rather than focusing on the location of the spotter, the operator focused his attention on the swinging sling.  The spotter stepped in front of the forklift to control the sling. The spotter was struck by the front left tyre, and his ankles and feet were seriously injured. The spotter was treated on site, and medivaced to a nearby hospital.

A cooling water failure to the depropanizer column overhead condenser initiated a rapid rise in column pressure. In response to the pressure rise a panel mounted, hand controlled, depressuring valve was opened fully to vent the pressure to the flare system. Upon opening the depressuring valve, high vibration in the column overhead pipework occurred. This vibration resulted in the fracturing of a 3/4' nipple on a vent line to fail. This resulted in an uncontrolled release of propane vapour to the atmosphere. No fire or explosion occurred. The potential for such was very high.

Following a planned shutdown of the onshore gas plant, a gas release occurred during re-start activities on Train 5. The loss of containment resulted when flanges installed in the liquid outlet on a Column were subjected to excessive load during the cool down process. This loading occurred because thermal movement of the pipe allowed it to exceed the height of the support guides resulting in a single point of support adjacent to the flanges. This support created the excessive flange bending moment.  The hydrocarbon release was classified as significant (RIDDOR Classification).

While on stand by, close to a platform for attending scaffolding activities, the vessel suddenly drifted and struck a platform leg. As a result of the action of the current, re-direction by choc effects, and crew reaction, the vessel then drifted to an other platform where its superstructures became entangled in scaffolding. As a result there was damage to the scaffolding structure, a number of pieces fell in the sea and onto the vessel deck, as well as damage to vessel superstructures, mast, antenna and radar. Fortunately, the scaffolders had left the area few minutes before.

A gas leak was caused from an instrument which was left in an open position. The gas leak caused production to shut down. The deluge system was released. During mustering  of all personnel the deluge water entered a junction box, which had been opened for maintenance before the gas leak. The water caused a short circuit of an Emergency Shut Down signal (ESD 1) which in turn caused the whole platform to shut in and power down.  During mustering due to the gas leak a person on his own walked back to his work place to close the junction box, which was left open when the alarm sounded.

A boat was on her way to rescue a Nigerian Oil Tanker in distress that was floating and drifting towards the A complex and SeaDril rig was detected 2.1 nautical miles from site by our security radar at 18h15. While the boat was sailing for the intervention mission, it lost control and struck the anti-collision bar around platform P1 and subsequent drifting and hitting platform P2.The platform was voluntarily shutdown and fully depressurisation and all personnel mustered. There was no injury to the personnel on board the platform and the rig. The vessel was towed out to a safe anchor buoy.

A shale shaker staff was working at the shale shaker area to clean a cutting. The Auger drill cutting removal is about 17.7-inch wide and 14.6-inch deep. The trough was covered with steel grating except at the shale shaker end where there was an opening of about 6.3-inch for cutting to fall inside the trough. As he stepped on the 6.3-inch opening on a grating that was covering the Auger, his left leg slipped trough into the Auger drill cutting removal and was caught in the rotating blade. He pulled out his left leg leaving behind his safety boot. He injured his left leg from ankle to knee.

While picking up a stand of drill pipe, the driller hit the derrick crown with the travelling block assembly, driving through the crown block safety braking system.  The crown-o-matic failed to stop the blocks from strking the crown due to faulty adjustment between the crown-o-matic and the brakes.  The drill line was severed and the entire travelling block assembly, kelly and joint of pipe fell uncontrolled to the rig floor from a height of approx 110 feet.  The motorman sustained a fractured scapula and abdominal injuries requiring surgery to repair.  The rig was down 15 days for repair.

An open flame was observed and smoke from the bottom of a welding habitat (pressurised tent).  The fire guard extinguished it immediately with a fire water hose.  No personnel were injured.  Investigation showed that due to the size and shape of the tent the fire guard could not view the work place fully nor was the flame gouging identified in the permit to work.  The area was not fully covered with fire blanket or metal sheeting.  The potential of the event was open fire on a live platform.  The situation was caused by insufficient work planning and lack of adherence to ex-isting procedures.

Electrician ESP units lease shop started to lay a cable KRBK 4.5 m long in cable rack. Works were accomplished at height with protective equipment (safety belt) used.  When laying cable for further movement along the rack the electrician disconnected the safety belt from the rack to connect it in the direction of movement. A ledge under him came off at a welding seam (the ledge of the cable structure bridge was made from a bar D=22 mm). The electrician did not manage to connect the safety belt and fell down to the ground from a height of 4.5 metres. His right forearm was injured in the  fall.

A Crude Oil Storage Tank was isolated for planned tank refurbishment work with remaining crude to be pumped to the Oily Water Pit by hoses connected to an air driven pump. As the level dropped. The access hole cover was removed to allow sighting of liquid level in the tank, thus ensuring continuous immersion of the hose end in the liquid. As the injured person released the hose and started to turn away, after making sure the hose end is immersed in the liquid, the hydrocarbon vapour around the opened access of the tank ignited, caused burns to his face and palms, and resulting in a flash fire.

At 12.55 hrs on 13th August 2007, an office boy of the drilling operation building noticed smoke and fire at the back of the office building. He immediately informed the HSE team. The team members rushed to the spot and found the fire in between the fences of the drilling office and the transport office, which are adjacent to each other. It was noticed that the fire was on dry plantation and spreading rapidly along the fence due to heavy winds. Immediately the fire station was informed and the people in the building were asked to evacuate. Meanwhile the fire team came and extinguished the fire.

Two contractor personnel were exposed to Hydrogen Sulphide while removing an isolation spade in a vessel vent line to the plant flare header which was live at the time. Both persons lost consciousness and were treated at the Field Medical Centre. As the emergency response was as per procedures the potential fatalities were determined as being two. Immediate causes: Inadequate risk assessment resulting in poor job planning, inadequate work procedures, inadquate hazard communication, poorly controlled hazards. Root Cause :Failure in the administration and application of the Permit to Work System.

The incident occurred while the injured person was tightening a leaking connection on a mud pump, middle piston rod lubricating system. The injured person used an adjustable wrench on the leaking connection and he placed his left hand down to brace himself while applying force. His foot slipped off the chain case and lube oil pump as he exerted force on the wrench. This caused his left hand to slip, from where it was anchored, down into the right piston coffin where it got caught between the moving pony rod/piston clamp and the face of the liner and was struck once before he pulled his hand out.

A drillship was laying out 13-3/8" casing onto the Forward Pipe Catwalk during drilling operations. A joint of casing was remotely landed on the mobile bucket using the tubular handling facility. The retaining arm was released and the operator then retracted the luffing arm. He then activated the roller park facility before the luffing arm was fully retracted, which resulted in the luffing arm moving upwards. The steel rod on the side of the luffing arm glanced the casing enough to push it out of the bucket and over the side of the catwalk. The casing joint swung uncontrolled towards the well centre.

During the skidding-in of the rig cantilever, a floorman was standing at the end of the rig main deck, guiding a cement hose with a rope. The cement hose was lifted up using an air winch in order for it to pass clear of the main deck hand rail (one hand rail was removed to facilitate easy passing of the cement hose). The cement hose was entangled with a bracket at the skidding beam, compressing it, and then suddenly it became free - causing spring movement which pushed the floorman overboard. The floorman, who was wearing a work vest, was recovered safely and checked by rig medic and found in good health.

An incident occurred during the launching of the Bengal Producer.   The Bengal Producer was tasked to pick up two Sangu employees from the Sangu Alpha platform on completion of their work day. During routine launching of the craft, an upset condition occurred which caused (three) members of the crew manning the Bengal Producer to enter the water as man overboard (MOB).  2 crew were recovered immediately closeby vessel, the 3rd crew member was swept away in 4-5 knot current, heading SSW ,and later rescued by a local fishing vessel and transferred to the OSV. All 3 crew members were recovered safe and well.

At the exit from the ROW to the asphalt road the trailer was moving along existing 500 mm gas pipeline and 1400 mm water pipeline. As the supervisor was engaged in welding activities (pipeline tie-in), he could not convoy the trailer during performance of a right turn and the driver failed to choose a correct radius and the trailer's right side wheel fell to below the road level.  Under the impact of its own weight (estimated 33 tones) the backhoe slid off the trailer and fell onto the ground. The 4 chains used to secure the backhoe from 4 sides on the trailer were torn. The trailer itself did not turn over.

The operation was washing in the hole with coiled tubing utilising 9.5ppg brine taking returns to the well test spread surge tank. Due to the fluid level in the left hand surge tank compartment, the well test company's operators intention was to switch to the right hand compartment. They should have opened the right hand valve first and then closed the left hand valve to avoid deadheading the system. However, they closed the left hand valve before opening the right hand valve.  This resulted in a system pressure increase and the pressure relief valve lifted discharging  brine into the sea via the relief line.

A worker was engaged in cable work activities at ground level of an LNG Tank.  At the same time insulation work was ongoing at an elevation on the same location and its work access provided by scaffold erected from the ground to the full height of the tank (approx. 36 metres). One of the scaffold tubes was handled unsafely on the scaffold and it fell from the scaffold striking the man who was working below. He sustained a cut to the head, fractured ribs, fractured thoracic vertabrae, internal bleeding, and paralysis in lower limbs. First aid was given immediately and further medical treatment was administered.

The tool pusher was leading 2 workers to disassemble low-pressure pipe, an assistant driller was leading another worker to repalce no 1 mud pump valve, and a floor man (IP) and another worker were screwing out the bolts of no 2 mud pump strainer. The IP was standing with his left foot under the low pressure pipe 15cm above the ground. The low pressure pipe was not supported from the bottom to prevent falling, in case of disassembling, neither was it attached from the top with any type of chain to ensure safe disassembling. The IP's foot was right under the pipe and was hit on his left foot by the falling pipe.

S61 crew change helicopter tail wheel impacted the helideck perimeter netting on landing due to inability to meet the sudden power requirement. The helicopter undercarriage came to rest on the edge of the helideck. The helideck was damaged but no damage occured to the helicopter and there were no injuries to the passengers or crew. The investigation could find no clear reason for the sudden power requirement, this was put down to local weather/turbulence. It was recommended that training of pilots who are not ex-military should emphasise the ability, if need be, to overtorque within reason, to prevent an accident.

Whilst drilling out a cement plug during workover, two 4-metre pup joints were picked-up and the Kelly reconnected. Circ press re-establish at 300psi, then a sudden change to 1000psi. The pup joints, a joint of tubing ejected from the well along with the Kelly and bushing. The assembly struck the driller's doghouse. Inadequate correction of prior hazard, in that the previous day the pack-off was not reported to base, inadequate work planning--provision of drill collars according to risk identified in prog, inadequate management of change when changing prog by drilling a shallow cement plug without formation isolation.

Whilst returning the FPSO•À_s cargo tank to service following an inspection, it was discovered that a mixture of inert gas and hydrocarbons had passed through the Pressure / Vacuum Valve breaker on the Main Inert Gas (MIG) inlets from the MIG header into 5 Port and Starboard Cargo Oil tanks.  The tanks had previously been gas feed to allow annual inspection by the Lloyds Surveyor. The worst realistic outcome would be an ignition source in a cargo tank with a flammable atmosphere that results in explosion of the tank. The likelihood of an ignition source is considered to be •À_•À_unlikely•À_•À_ since tank equipment is Ex rated.

At 20:30 an assistant driller from an external contractor company of Naighbors Drilling International Limited  (born in 1982) during implementation of operations associated with cleaning of dirt on dismantled panel of drilling rig shelter panel received injuries as a result of the panel falling from an unstable position. The diagnosis:  fracture of 6, 7, 8 ribs on the right along middle underarm line. Bruises of soft tissues of the right shoulder joint.  Rupture of spleen capsule.  He was hospitalized in Irkutsk clinical hospital on 25.07.2010. Currently the casualty is in resuscitation department, his condition is stable.

A three person corrosion monitoring crew was in the well house removing a corrosion coupon. When the coupon plug was removed from the access fitting, the tool operator heard a hissing sound he interpreted as a leaking hammer union. In the process of replacing the coupoon plug, the tool operator accidently opened the service valve and bleed valve simultaneously. The bleed valve allowed more gas to reach the bleed than it could vent, and the can ruptured into 2 pieces with enough force to propel it across the well house. The tool operator immediately closed the bleed valve and re-inserted the coupon plug to isolate the pressure.

The accident occurred during a project to repair port aft column equipment on a converted Aker H-3 semi submersible following a catastrophic flooding incident. The person involved was installing temporary lights in the void space. There were no witnesses to the accident but the evidence indicates he fell 2.9m from a mezzanine deck. He was conscious alert and complaining of a headache. He was taken to a hospital and died following emergency surgery to relieve pressure from internal bleeding. Critical factors in the accident: working aloneack of familiarity with worksite no safety harness, unprotected height hazard, no task risk.

At approximately 1100 hrs one ROW worker was injured while cutting a tree at Kp-53. He was 'medivaced' to Yangon hospital and received treatment. The IP was assigned to transfer timbers and bamboo and when the need arose he was to cut down the tree and carry it to the work area. The tree suddently swung out of control and hit the IP on the right side of the head. The IP was working alone when the accident happened. His friend heard him scareaming and rushed to the scene and found him laying beside the tree that he had been felling. His right eye was swollen and his nose bleeding. The site Medic arrived and administered first aid.

In the middle of the storage-yard in a safe area the separator No S-101, polluted with pirophoric materials was planned to clean. Opening the entering hole the separator was monitored for 1 day, then the other flanges were also taken off. As the downer level control flange was opened, the glowing material ignited the CH mix in the separator, and a fire ball was shot through the  previously opened water discharge line. At that time the victim arrived to call the colleagues for lunch. He was hit by the fireball, and had serious burning injuries on his leg. His colleagues took him to the doctor, and the ambulance took him to the clinic.

An incident occurred on a stand-by vessel when launching the Fast Rescue Craft for a routine exercise resulting in the uncontrolled release of the FRC, dropping 10m to sea level. The FRC was immediately recovered.  Fortunately no crew fell overboard; however, the impact from the fall has resulted in all three crew sustaining injuries. The coast guard was notified and a medical evacuation helicopter mobilised. The injured crew were taken to hospital for treatment and X-rays.  2 of the 3 crew have now been released having suffered bruising. The third crew member has sustained fractures to both ankles and possibly has chipped a bone in his spine.

The injured employees of the sub-contractor were releasing the slop vessel desulphurer from fats as part of the yearly maintenance activities. The employees were using a high voltage searchlight, which was not an explosion proof product, inside the vessel during the release. The workers noticed strange and bad smells. The sub-contractor did not inform the customer about the smells and the usage of the light. One of them came up from the vessel to take a fresh air respirator in order to continue his work inside.  10-15 minutes after his return an explosion occurred inside the vessel. The workers were harmed by the heat and suffered burn injuries.

The drill string of 3-1/2'' DP was composed of two types of DP the G 105 and S 135. When pulling out of hole and laying down joints, G 105 were laid down first with no problem. A first joint of S 135 came out and was positionned in the V-door. The driller asked the roughnecks to reposition the S 135 in order to separate G 105 from S 135. To do this, a roughneck stands at the tugger to elevate the DP and the other stands by to control and reposition the DP. An incorrect elevator was used, the ID of the same was bigger then the OD of DP's tool joint and the pipe was free to slide; at this point the elevator came free hitting the roughneck in the face.

A gasket leak was found on the dehydration regeneration circuit.  During a routine check, a gas leak was detected.  On investigation a gas leak was discovered at the downstream side of the non return valve on the dehydration regeneration line.  A Lower Explosive Limit (LEL) check was immediately carried out and this confirmed an LEL reading of 60% approximately 10 metres downwind of the leak.  This was reported to the Central Control Room (CCR) and Shift Superintendent.  A second visit was then carried out with the Shift Superintendent and discovered the leak had ceased due to increased regeneration temperature expanding the pipe work thus stopping the flow.

A field specialist was performing an injectivity test for a well. Coiled Tubing (CT) reel had to be spotted on the I-beam which was 1.5m above the deck floor. To get a clearer view for spooling, the field specialist had to stand on top of a container which was 2.45 m above deck level to give a signal to the Coiled Tubing operator inside control cabin. Later, he noticed the portable crane boom was swinging very fast towards where he was standing. He jumped off the container and landed on both legs but slipped due to the wet and slippery floor caused by heavy rain. He suffered tenderness at several locations of his body and some bones were suspected to be broken.

A Transport Truck arrived on location to pull a load of Condensate. When preparing to hook up to the tank and open the valves, the driver observed a leak coming from the bottom of Condensate Tank # 1. The Field Operator was notified, and he proceeded to the location to assess the situation after dispatching more trucks to offload the condensate. The operator found a small hole at the bottom of the tank and was able to temporarily stop the leak. The Condensate Tank was emptied and trucks arrived on location to begin the cleanup. It was calculated that approx. 11 bbls of condensate spilled and all of the fluid was contained inside the lined secondary containment.

During commissioning of a new compressor, the compressor was due for a 4 hour long test (continuous operation). It was planned that regulated air pressure, from a compressed-air tank (maximum capacity of 50 m3), would be used.  The air pressure was to be regulated between 25 and 27 barg, using bleeding equipment consisting of a 5m long 2" hose (connected to the tank by a flange), with a ball valve and a silencer at the free end. During the operation the silencer exploded and the hose moved about in an uncontrolled fashion, causing injury to personnel and material. The ball valve had broken off and the hose was in continuous movement for approximatly 15 minutes.

Contractors were issued a hot work permit as part of a major overhaul activity on a crude oil tank. During the contractors lunch break the operations department conducted draining operations on a crude oil tank upstream of the contractors work area. The contractors returned to work and started a mobile generator that ignited vapours from the crudeoil/water in the drain channel. Potential for 2 fatalities. Immediate causes: Poor planning of draining operations, Ineffective continuous monitoring, Lack of communication, inadequate risk assessment regarding concurrent operations. Root Cause: Failure in the administration and application of the Permit to Work System.

A fire caused by tube failure on a mol sieve regen heater resulted in US$170,000 damage, but no injuries.  When a regen gas tube in the upper section of the regen gas heater ruptured at about 150 psig, regen gas escaped into the heater plenum and ignited.  A regen gas heater shutdown alarm was received in the control room. The operator left the control room to check the shutdown, immediately saw the fire, initiated fire alarms, and started firewater pumps. Other operators/plant personnel started fire monitors to cool surrounding equipment and used a 1-1/2 inch fire hose to cool the DCS conduit. Closing the remote inlet valve to the heater immediately killed the fire.

Following the cementation of the 7" liner and during the subsequent circulation of the wellbore drilling fluids, an explosion of unknown origin occurred on the rig drill floor. This resulted in two steel plate access panels and drain covers in the rig floor above the electric motor compartment underneath the rig floor being lifted and displaced. Prior to the ignition a LEL (gas) detector located in this compartment had activated which initiated a general muster of all personnel. The well was shut-in and made safe with the drill crew proceeding to muster with the exception of the Toolpusher and Driller who remained in a safe area on the drill floor to monitor the well.

At about 1645 hrs, the contractor's crew was having difficulty removing the MOV Actuator from the valve due to severe corrosion between two items. A technician assisted in performing the job and proceeded to use a hydraulic hand jack and chisel to split the MOV actuator from the valve. While he was hammering the chisel, suddenly the chisel gave way and flew into the air then penetrated through the left eye brow of a person who was observing the job nearby. He sustained a lacerated wound with a 3 cm entry site and 1 cm exit site. Medical treatment was given by the medic on board, then he was referred to the nearest clinic the next day for further observation and treatment.

At about 14:45 on the North side of a compressor on ground level an air-blowing pre-commissioning activity was ongoing. The pressure released from the 10" (inch) diameter pipe blast blew off an empty cable drum (around 2m diameter and 50 kg) located at about 5m in front of the pipe. The "projectile" rolled on a distance of 15 meters and hit a passer-by (contractor) on the back of his lower left leg. He received a big shock and fell-down on the paved ground floor. He was stabilized by the medical team before to be taken to the site clinic. The victim underwent an X-ray (negative result, no fractures) and a Voltaren injection. He returned to work the next day in the morning.

A skid-mounted land operated drilling rig was being road transported to the Onshore Terminal construction site (a distance of approximately 80km). The drilling rig was loaded onto a trailer and bolted down to the trailer. The trailer was pulled by a 4x4 vehicle. The trailer has no shock absorbers with the result that it does not ride smoothly. During the journey, the bumper/tow bar on the 4x4 broke away, the trailer inclined forward until the tow bar hit the road. The trailer then skidded along the road for about 20 ft until it hit the hard shoulder. At that point, the trailer tipped over, the bolts securing the rig to the trailer broke and the rig catapulted from the trailer.

A spacer ring, weighing 2,2 kilos, fell from a work platform under the crane tip to a walkway 12 metres below and missed a person who was walking there by 0,5 metres.  No personnel were injured, however the potential event was severe injury to personnel, possibly fatal.  The hazard of losing tools and equipment was not identified in the risk evaluation.  Protective barriers were not required in the permit to work, the crane(s) were not locked during the maintenance work.  Generally the work preparation and information preceding the work was inadequate.  The requirements for working in heights and work preparations for cold work were not sufficiently addressed in the procedures.

An explosion occurred at the construction site resulting in 4 instant deaths and 17 injured 4 of them with serious injury, one of them dying the day after. After investigation, it was found that the construction team was storing gas cylinders (oxygen & acetylene) in a container every evening. In order to avoid theft of the equipment at night, the worker would tag weld the doors of the container. The accident occurred when the workers were in the process of grinding the welds to open the doors. No bottle was found exploded, and we can assume that an accumulation of acetylene from a leaking cylinder was ignited by the sparks of the grinding machine used for breaking the welds.

A 10 tonne truck crane was used to lift a bar bending yard to a tankage construction area. The lifting work was monitored by an area HSE Promoter. After the rebar was loaded onto the truck crane, the operator went down to the outrigger control point to retract the outrigger. The rigger climbed out and stood on the right extended rear side to set and push some protruding rebars into the crane bucket. While the operator on duty retracted the rear side of the outrigger, he heard the rigger scream. The job was immediately stopped. The HSE Promoter and a nearby staff rushed to the incident area and found the rigger's legs trapped in between the upper portion outrigger and the crane•À_s body.

A contractor was performing well servicing operations.  The crew had completed their work for the day and were in the dog house changing their clothes.  When the crew remembered that they needed to fully open a surface casing valve to relieve pressure on the casing, one employee who had already changed out of his work clothes went alone to open the valve.  Although no other employees witnessed the accident, it is believed that when the employee opened the ball valve, the blow down line whipped across the location and struck him simultaneously in both legs. His legs were broken and subsequently both legs had to be amputated. The employee also sustained a fracture of the right shoulder scapula.

After performing a flow check on a wiper trip, the driller ran the blocks up the derrick for another stand.  The derrickman had been sitting in the heated shelter (-30 degrees C working conditions) during the flow check.  The derrickman exited the shelter and communicated that he was ready, however he had removed the lateral restraint line while in the shelter and failed to re-attach prior to beginning work.  He grabbed the stand and proceded to throw it in the elevators.  Expecting the support of the lateral restraint, the worker lost his balance and fell into the elevators.  The worker was wearing his full harness and fall arrest line, which engaged.  Worker sustained only a minor cut above his left eye.

A Bi-directional Pig was being launched from a temporary pig launcher to de-water a pipeline after hydrostatic testing. The motive power for the launch was air supplied through a flexible hose from a mobile air compressor. The air compressor was started and the air supply to the launcher was isolated by a single block valve. The Safety Officer was standing at the door of the launcher checking the correct position of the pig when the bi-directional pig reversed back out of the launcher door and hit him in the face causing serious injuries. A Detailed Investigation determined that a Job Hazard Analysis should have been conducted and implemented to manage the hazards associated with this non routine operation.

A Bi-directional Pig was being launched from a temporary pig launcher to de-water a pipeline after hydrostatic testing. The motive power for the launch was air supplied through a flexible hose from a mobile air compressor. The air compressor was started and the air supply to the launcher was isolated by a single block valve. The Safety Officer was standing at the door of the launcher checking the correct position of the pig when the bi-directional pig reversed back out of the launcher door and hit him in the face causing serious injuries. A detailed investigation determined that a Job Hazard Analysis should have been conducted and implemented to manage the hazards associated with this non routine operation.

A bundle of drill pipe was being lowered into a storage bay with two tag lines attached and under the control of two personnel. At approximately six feet above the deck, the load suddenly swung due to the motion of the rig, and the end of the bundle collided with an adjacent oxy-acetylene cylinder rack frame. The cylinder rack was knocked over onto the gantry crane track and came to rest. This caused three of the six cylinders within the rack to dislodge from the rack and they came to rest adjacent to the rack. The three cylinders which became dislodged had caps protecting the valves, however two of the other cylinders did not. The closest observer was approximately 8ft away from the rack at the time of incident.

At approx 2:30 pm both waterflood turbines went down apparently due to high flow or overspeed.  Several operators went to investigate and discovered an underground leak near the lateral isolation valves.  They put on air packs and attempted to close the isolation valves.  The catwalk was inaccessible due to hot water spray, so the operators walked on the east lateral to reach the valves.  An operator slipped and fell on the ground in several inches of hot water, burning his left side.  The operator was carried to the waterflood control room for first aid.  Several minutes later the 10inch underground 'jumper' line connecting the east and south laterals ruptured, creating a large hole and releasing produced water.

Contractor crew were loading a tubing elevator into a metal storage box at the main deck using the port side crane. The box cover could not be secured in the open position using the support bar due to the unit being in close proximity. The victim was holding back the box cover and resting his left hand on the edge of the box. After the load was released, the signal man signaled to the crane perator to pick up the block. While the crane block was being picked up, the sling thimble hung up on the box edge and the cover fell down into the closed position on the victim's left thumb. He sustained a fracture of the left thumb with superficial abrasion, and was medivaced to the base for further medical evaluation and treatments.

While attempting to repair the stripper column overhead pressure control Valve that had failed closed, two operators were trying to maintain the column operating pressure utilising a bypass globe valve around the column overhead relief valve. There was not a dedicated specification bypass around the failed control valve. Whilst adjusting the globe valve to adjust the column pressure the 3 inch bypass line root weld connection to the 18 inch flare line failed causing a major toxic gas release which resulted in the activation of the plant isolation and blowdown system. Potential for 4 fatalities. Immediate causes: Using a system for which it was not designed inadequate risk assessment. Root Cause: lack of operating procedures

At 13:00 hrs a senior production crew were working to refill Emulsotron RL 6321, a flammable chemical into a daily tank from drum by opening the valve of connection hose with a small stream and using elevation method. The location of the daily tank was close to one of the open drain line access points on the main deck. At the same time Welders start working to joint a 4" open drain line underneath the main dek. A pop sound was heard at 15:00 hrs, all concerned tried to find the source the  sound and found a small fire in the chemical tank area. The small fire were safely extinghuised at 15:02 hrs, by production and safety team using a portable CO2 extinguisher  (1ea). The fire could have spread due to chemical drums in surrounding area.

Whilst drilling with the elevators approximately 1-1.5 meters above the rotary table, the Driller stated that he was picking up to make a connection when a larger heave than had been experienced came through, resulting in the attempt to pull-out of the hole quickly to stop the elevators from making contact with the drill floor. The subsequent series of actions resulted in the blocks impacting the drill floor in an uncontrolled manner. As a consequence, the drill line paid out rapidly from the draw-works and severed at the wire retention socket of the (draw works) drum. Following the severing of the drill-line, approximately 60 meters of 1 •À__ inch drill line was projected up the derrick, over the fast line sheave and fell to the drill floor.

During implementation of hot jobs associated with dismantling of a pipeline (•À_•À_=426x8mm) at a decommissioned Central Processing Facility within a central gathering facility by a crew of 4 persons, a pop of gas with following ignition took place. At 14:15 the ignition was extinguished by resources of the fire unit. As a result of the ignition burns on various parts of the body were received by an electric and gas welder of grade 5. The casualty was rendered first pre-doctor aid, after which by an ambulance the casualty was transported to resuscitation department of the city hospital. The diagnosis:  thermal flame burns of the head, back, buttocks, back surface of hips of level 1-3 up to 50% of the body surface. Compensated burn shock of level 1-2.

A truck was delivering interconnecting concrete beams to the retaining wall area. While traveling down the hill to the retaining wall site, the truck's front wheel sank into a soft spot on the edge of the road. The driver had a couple of workers fill in the soft spot with rocks and then the truck proceeded to drive down the hill. As the truck's rear wheel went through the soft spot, the wheel sunk due to the weight of the concrete beams, and tipped the back of the truck causing some of the concrete beams to fall. One of the workers who had placed the rocks in the soft spot was struck by and pinned between the beams and the soft hillside. The beams were lifted off the worker and he was taken to the hospital. Injured person suffered multiple fractures.

During the off-loading of containers from the supply boat to the offshore platform, the first officer was directing the operation, but located in a blind spot.  As the lifting began, the first officer was trapped by a guide rope hanging from the container with a loop at the end, and was dragged against the bannister of the boat. The crew was unable to release him and they had to open the bannister letting the man fall into the water, since the vessel was moving away from the platform. The crew threw him a life buoy and launched the life boat. Thirty minutes after falling into the water, the rescue team managed to cut the rope and move him onboard the platform for medical attention and helicopter evacuation. The officer suffered multiple leg fractures.

On attempting to start a compressor, it was found that it failed. The problem was discussed and it was concluded that it could be down to the circuit breaker which had given rise to similar probems in the past. The circuit breaker (13.5kV) was racked out of position and the start relay operation observed and seen to be working correctly. The circuit breaker was then racked back into postion. However, the breaker was in the closed position and should have been prevented from being racked into postion by electrical and mechanical interlocks. These failed to operate and the result was and explostion within the circuit breaker cubicle which destroyed the breaker and caused some minor burns on one of the electrical technicians. Could have been 2 fatalities.

After completing the bottom hole flowing pressure survey (BHFP), a dummy valve was run and got stuck at 100 ft. and lost its jar action.  After unsuccessful attempts to release the stuck dummy valve, it was decided to drop the cutter to cut the wire above the tool string.  While preparing for the above operations, the cross over connecting the lubricator with x-mass tree cap slipped off, leading to an uncontrolled pressure release to the atmosphere.  The helper who was standing on the wellhead platform near by the cross over was blasted in the face by well pressure before he jumped to the ground to escape. The supervisor on site immediately closed the swab valve and kept the well under control.  The injured person was evacuated to the hospital by ambulance.

While transporting 2 pipes a contractor trailer was being towed by a bulldozer with a steel rope. At a distance of 100 m from the bottom of the hill, the tow rope of the tandem-axle semitrailer suddenly broke away  because of a sudden jerk of the trailer by the bulldozer. Thus two pipes and the semitrailer rolled back down to the bottom of the hill. There was damage to the pipes and the semitrailer body only. The SWL of the rope was 18t, the total weight of the pipes 15t. The total weight of the tandem-axle semitrailer body was 1.5t. But the rope's clips did not withstand the weight of the load and the rope slipped out of the clips. The clips were not tightened properly before the work. That was not checked by either the driver or mechanics before the trip.

While a contractor was carrying out mechanical excavation, 5 fiber optic communication cables were cut. Due to the cut, all communication between the Central Degassing Station (CDS) and five Remote Degassing Stations (RDS) was lost and all RDSs were shutdown resulting in loss of production volume approximately 30,000 bbls.  Two production trains were also shut down at CDS.  Due to the shut down at RDS No. 5, high pressure developed in a flowline from Bb-300 causing flowline rupture, resulting in estimated spillage of 37 bbls of crude oil into the ground and release of gases into the air.  Bb-304 flowline also developed a pinhole leak. The Remote Degassing Stations started back and wells no. Bb-300 & 304 were closed and flowlines were isolated for repair.

Backfilling of excavated trench of a 12" gas pipeline with sand was in progress with the help of a Tipper Truck in the field. During this operation, the driver of the Tipper Truck took the vehicle in reverse direction close to the excavated site and unloaded the sand directly from the tipper truck to excavated trench. After this operation, the driver forgot to reset the tipper body to its original position and took forward the vehicle in the same condition. In the process he also ignored watching the 11 KV overhead electrical transmission lines which are just above the site.  As a result, the front portion of the Tipper which was in elevated position hit with the electrical high voltage transmission line.  Fortunately nothing happened. No Injuries. No damages.

Steam Turbine Alternator Catastrophic Failure. The fracture and drop out of an internal bracing bar in the fan housing caused the No. 1 steam turbine fan to break up.  This shattered the gearbox pinion bearings and stripping of the turbine coupling bolts.   The coupling parted, and the tails of the coupling bolts were bent up into the open coupling faces. The physical damage caused variation in oil pressure which allowed the governor valves to open, probably fully, to try to restore turbine speed to the set point.  The effect of the steam flow into the turbine, which was disconnected from the gearbox etc, caused massive turbine acceleration.  In turn this led to centrifugal loss turbine blades, causing imbalance and bending of the shaft leading to its failure.

While flowing well to the test separator and diverting produced water to filtration vessel for filtration, a vessel hatch cover came loose sending produced water and the cover into the air. The cover measured 13.75•À_•À_ x 17.65•À_•À_ and weighed approximately 15 lbs. After traveling an estimated 25•À_ in the air, it landed several feet away from the filtration unit on the top deck. Although personnel were in the area of the unit, no injuries occurred and all the liquid was contained by secondary containment. The equipment was immediately shutdown, the carbon vessel was taken out of service and the area was secured. A facility investigation was completed the following day and the team determined the filter and cover had not been properly installed at the fabrication yard.

The involved person (IP) was part of a work team on night shift for external fence erection. The shift started at 21.00 hrs. The IP wandered outside of the work area without informing either his supervisor or his colleagues. This was shortly after arrival at the worksite. At the end of the shift it was noticed that he was missing but assumed that he had gone back to the camp. Upon arriving at the camp a search was initiated with no results. The morning shift arrived at 0500 and found a person lying badly injured at the bottom of a cliff near the work area. The IP was found and medics mobilised. He stabilised and medevaced to the nearest hospital by road. It was later discovered that a tree had broken the IP's fall, although he still sustained severe head injuries.

Casing was being racked in stands in the derrick using the offline work station and Pipe Racking System (PRS). The 41st stand was racked in the fingers and the latch (restraining device) was observed to be down. The PRS was then retracted to collect the next stand. Shortly afterwards, stand 41 fell across the derrick and lodged precariously on the end forward casing finger. The drill floor was cleared of personnel and a plan was devised to recover the stand of casing using an air tugger. During the recovery attempt, the casing fell to port and landed on the port crane (boom wire) where it bounced and the top joint (45ft of casing) fell overboard into the sea. The other 2 joints of casing came to rest on the end of the crane boom with the lower end on the drill floor.

A Contractor Company crew was performing workover of the well pad. At 16:30 when pulling out of the hole with NV-32 pump, making up of an adjusting semi-rod on the polished rod resulted in sponateous movement of fully unloaded rod string downwards. This resulted in squeezing of the right hand of a senior operator between the sucker-rod tongs and the guide nipple. The casualty was rendered first pre-doctor aid, an ambulance was called in, the casualty was transported to the city hospital. The diagnosis: open fracture and displacement of the base of the main phalanx on the right hand finger 1, subcapital fracture of the main phalanx on the right hand finger 1, open fracture of nail phalanx on the right hand finger 1, avulsive wounds on the back surface of the right hand.

Workers were found to have removed an earthing resistor without having a permit to work or any authorization to enter the transformer area. The earthing resister was connected to the live 33kV busbar at substation #3. This area was clearly defined by CSU orange fencing and warning tape. The cable connecting the 33kV switchboard transformer resistor had been disconnected from earth at the secondary side of the transformer, thus leaving the 33kV switchboard without earth fault protection, as the alternative earthing transformer to the 33KV switchboard had been isolated. This situation could have been potentially lethal to any one in the area if a fault had occurred whilst the earthing resistor was disconnected. Work was stopped and workmen were pulled out from work site.

At 10:45 am a complete power shutdown was initiated, following the activation of an ESD push button located at a lifeboat station. As a consequence the rig was left with no power generation, no Uninterrupted Power System (UPS) and then with no possibility to maintain and monitor her position above the well. The yellow alert was raised shortly followed by the red alert. The Emergency Disconnect Sequence (EDS) was therefore initiated by the Driller, shearing the completion string and disconnecting the Lower Marine Riser Package (LMRP). The drillship started drifting until it was maintained in position by 2 tugboats (about 2 NM away from well location). ERC (Emergency Response Centre) was locally activated. On the drillship, dynamic positioning functions were restored at 7 pm.

When starting gas injection in a converted well, three consecutive gas leaks occurred on the modified equipment. The last one led to automatic shut down. It was initiated by gas detector indications of 90 % and 105 % LEL. The first leak was due to an open pipe end in a bleed line to the flare. The second one was caused by a valve wrongly mounted in back-seat position with subsequent damage to gaskets. The third leak came from a flange where the bolt nuts had been tightened with an insufficient torque. Among main causes: Modified equipment was accepted for operation without being properly checked out. Mechanical completion had not been verified and no leak testing had been done _•À_•À_ There had been insufficient management follow-up of this one and a half year modification project.

An explosion occurred in an oily water drain sump during hot work to extend the height of the atmospheric vent line. The sump and drain system had recently been tied into an existing online oily drainage system. A detailed investigation determined that the isolation plug fitted in the oily drain system was not of the correct specification to prevent the migration of hydrocarbon vapours into the hot work site. Gas testing was not conducted immediately prior to commencement of welding, and the sample tube used was not of sufficient length to sample the bottom of the sump. Recommendations from the investigation included the need for a Job Hazard Analysis to be performed and a review of isolation standards to ensure that stopple plugs of the correct specifications are used in future.

The supply vessel was snatching deck cargo at the platform. After the loading and offloading operation, Platform Crane Operators and supply vessel crews were moving the mini-containers to the starboard side of the vessel to keep clear the emergency laydown area on the boat deck. At 1413 hrs, while lifting the 2nd mini container, the vessel rolled to portside causing the lifted container to swing towards the centre line of the deck and the pallet of chemicals. The injured person then moved from his position on the forward side of the container to the inboard side in an attempt to arrest its movement. The container gained extra momentum and pushed the injured person against the pallet of chemicals. The injured person sustained a slight fracture to his 5th rib on the left-hand side.

A 14•À_•À_ high pressure header was isolated from the wells with all production going into the IP or LP parts of the system. All six of the 8•À_•À_ HP header inlet valves were closed. Each of these valves was fitted with a 1•À_•À_ bypass line and ball valve to allow for equalization to facilitate the opening of the valves when the wells need to be redirected. The ball valve was of a screwed body and connection type and the pipe-work was also connected using screwed fittings. The incident involved three of these 1•À_•À_ valves failing, two immediately and one a few moments later, with the body breaking apart at the screwed connection and the ball being ejected from the valve. This resulted in a significant gas release. The Production Operators made an immediate decision to shut down the gas plant.

An explosion occurred in an oily water drain sump during hot work to extend the height of the atmospheric vent line. The sump and drain system had recently been tied into an existing online oily drainage system. A Detailed Investigation  determined that the isolation plug fitted in the oily drain system was not of the correct specification to prevent the migration of hydrocarbon vapours into the hot work site. Gas testing was not conducted immediately prior to commencement of welding, and the sample tube used was not of sufficient length to sample a the bottom of the sump. Recommendations from the investigation included the need for a Job Hazard Analysis to be performed and a review of isolation standards to ensure that stopple plugs of the correct specifications are used in future.

Contractor workers were involved in cathodic protection work on a steel re-bar cage structure at the Quay wall. About 50 workers were working at this area. Some workers were on top of the cage structure, some were standing on planks supported on the cage wall at an intermediate height, while some were at the base of the cage on the Quay wall. At the same time a few steel-fixers were at the same location carrying out adjustment work to the steel cage and removing temporary supports. Unexpectedly, the re-bar cage slid and collapsed on the workers causing injury to 18 workers. A crane was used to lift some of the collapsed cage structure off the workers. A near by Medical emergency team was called. An ambulance arrived and the injured personnel were moved to Hospital for further treatment.

A hydraulic jack, that was being used to lift a 36" gas line lost hydraulic pressure, failed. A 2nd jack of a different style was tried, but failed to lift the pipe sufficiently. The piping sup'r asked a crane operator to lift the pipe using an 80 tonne crane. The crane was brought into position and the lift attempted.  Shortly after commencing, the crane overload alarms sounded & the operator manually overrode them. Eventually the crane boom deformed and failed, though it could have collapsed, resulting in fatalities of those working in the area.  The crane operator had no training on this type of crane, overrode safety critical devices, site procedures did not identify competency deficiences in operator, inadequate management of change, leadership and assessement of needs and risks.

During maintenance a 10_„ pipe end was left open. In this state a process shut down with flaring took place. This caused gas to flow through the open pipe end. The leak was not detected automatically because wind blowed the gas away. While flaring, the flame went out. A person was told to use a signal pistol to relight the flame and to shoot from a position in the area where gas was leaking out, not knowing about the leak. Being ready to shoot, he heard the gas leak. The leak was then stopped by closing a valve manually. The potential for material damage and personnel injury was high. Among main causes: Safety assessment prior to the maintenance job was insufficient - The maintenance operators believed they had blocked the free passage to the atmosphere,  but they had shut a wrong valve.

On 22nd September 2011, at approximately 11:30 Hrs, an inspection was planned to assess the integrity of BCDS heaters. The crew obtained a work permit and associated certificates to execute the task. There was no Task Risk Assessment (TRA) performed and there was no formal working procedure for the installation of burners of the heater. The heater was isolated and eight burners were removed. After inspection and repairs, the heater was being assembled for installation. Our labourers were using chain block to lift the burner. Vane blades of the burner were used as lifting lug and due to excessive tension/stress lead to slippage of the burner and the burner fell down on to the erected scaffolding. Outcome: Two labourers were struck by the falling burner and sustained minor facial injuries.

While preparing installation of a X-mas tree a heavy object, a SUB weighing about 190 kilos, fell from the catwalk onto the drill floor and then through the mouse hole in the drill floor. The object continued to fall bout 14 meters down to a landing platform in the moonpool area where it hit a person working there. This person later died. Immediate causes were: Loose objects on the catwalk - Insufficient covering of the mouse hole - Poor communication between driller and deceased person. Underlying causes were:  A HAZOP for the lifting and installation of the X-mas tree had been carried out onshore, but the safety measures identified in the HAZOP were not implemented - A proper lifting and installation procedure had not been prepared - Weak safety awareness with both management and crew.

Wireline crew were in the process of rigging down the lubricator as work had finished. The Wireline Crew consisted of a Wireline Winch Operative, a Senior Wireline Operator, a Wireline Assistant and a Platform Crane Operator. At the time of the incident the crew were ready to cut the wire to release the tool so they could wind the wire back on the drum. The Wireline assistant at this point took the decision to cut the wire on his own (at NO time was the operative in the worksite on his own), which as explained is a task completed by them on a regular basis. The process to follow was to grab hold of the wire running to the drum, move the wire close to the deck, place one leg of the wire cutters resting up against the deck and, with the person's free hand, operate the cutters to cut the wire.

Impairment of platform's HP flare system by filling with seawater:  One pair of bursting discs, protecting the shell side of a gas cooler, ruptured below set pressure while in service.  Seawater flowed through the bursting discs into the HP flare system.  Alarm did not activate. High level of water in the flare drum automatically initiated a production shutdown but not a depressurization. Seawater shutdown valve closed automatically, but did not prevent seawater being pumped into the gas cooler and on to the HP flare drum. Seawater pumps remained online. The HP flare drum and HP flare pipe work were filled with water before the source of the liquid was determined. The HP flare system was rendered unavailable for hydrocarbon blow down while full of seawater. Non-essential personnel were evacuated.

The port crane was being used to lift the anchor chain J-Hook from the supply vessel to its storage hang off point at the rig port aft. The injured person was banksman and 2 other men were handling the load. The injured person was standing between the storage post and rail in front of the port aft anchor winch area and was in visual contact with the C.O. The injured person signalled to lift up slightly so the shackle on the shank of the J-Hook could slide onto the hang off pin. However, the J-Hook shackle came up tight under the pin and cracked the weld on the underside and the pin bent upwards. The reactive force caused the hook to swing towards and against the injured person's torso, pushing him against the hand rail behind him. The C.O. moved the J-Hook away lifting and landing it on the riser deck.

Two members of the sites demolition team accidently cut into a 20 inch pipe containing gas at 1.7 barg. The pipe was cut on the wrong side of the isolation, the workscope having been misunderstood by the contractor. A site procedure relating to marking of pipes had not been followed. An estimated 162 kg of gas was released to the atmosphere. The gas was not ignited and was dispersed in an open area. There was no injury to personnel. The affected plant was shut down and depressured. At the time of the incident the 2 members of the demolition work party were positioned approximately 1m from the locus of the cut in a cherry picker basket. The 12v electrical control panel for the cherry picker located in a panel at the rear of the basket was not EX certified and so represented a potential source of ignition.

A temporary pump, driven by an internal combustion engine, was being used for an offloading operation from a gasoline road tanker onto a fuel tank on a production facility. This pump was positioned inside the bundwall. When the operation was almost completed, the operator (with 8 years experience) went to look for the supervisor to obtain his conformity. When the operator came back, the fuel tank was overflowing and spilling petrol inside the bundwall. The operator rushed to shut the valve. At that moment, the pump engine ignited the pool of petrol, causing 2nd degree burns to the operator and to the tanker driver. The speedy action of personnel allowed rapid extinction of the fire, which otherwise could have propagated through the production plant and a series of oil tanks, leading to a mayor catastrophe.

On 7th April 2010, in a Drilling rig, at around 03:45hrs, the rig crew was testing the BOP Blind Shear ram. After testing to 15,000 PSI, the night pusher bled the pressure back to the testing unit to zero and asked the floor man to close the manual valve next to the check valve. The IP was asked to disconnect the quick latch coupling of the test hose from the hammer union hook up to the lower kill line. While doing so, he slipped and the hose detached from the quick latch connection. As a result the fluid came out through the broken quick latch fitting of the hammer union like a jet and hit the right hand arm above the elbow. It appears that the pressure was not bled fully and there was trapped pressure behind the fitting. First Aid was administered to the IP, and he was taken to the hospital for further treatment.

During rig up operations, a critical lift was being performed to attach the 3.5 ton skid mounted derrick board to the derrick.  Two forklifts (one on drillers' side and one on pit side) used to raise the board appox 9" off ground & into position for pinning.  While attempting to intall pin on drillers' side, board slid off forks, overbalanced, & tumbled 90 degrees towards catwalk.  This resulted in employee being thrown to the ground, with board coming to rest in an upright position, with derrick board frame surrounding employee. The crew failed to recognise this as a critical lift (use of 2 forklifts), there was no rig move plan nor JSA for the job task.  Leadership need to reinforce the lifting policy, evaluate all changes made to ensure a new unsafety condition is not introduced.  Reinforce "Stop Work" expectation.

The pilot positioned the helicopter for a west-southwest departure from an offshore platform due to prevailing wind conditions. After clearing the edge of the helideck, the helicopter started a slow yaw to the right. The pilot added full left pedal; however, this did not stop the rotation. After 360 degrees of rotation, the rotation quickened, the pilot stated that he "didn't have a tail rotor," and lowered the collective and rolled the throttle to idle. The pilot deployed the emergency floats, and the helicopter impacted the water slightly nose low and in a right drift. The helicopter rolled over immediately to the right and stayed afloat. The pilot egressed the helicopter through the broken windscreen area, the left seat pilot egressed through the pilot's open door, and the passenger egressed through the left passenger door.

During de-rigging of coil rigdown operations, the coil tubing injector head was lifted from the lower frame section and placed on the drill floor, immediately in front of the V-door. The coiled tubing remained connected to the injector head. A winch outside the dog house was connected to the injector head to act as a snub line. The next step was to attach a threaded lifting cap to a 2nd winch to lift the BOP stack off the riser, and place it on its stand. At this point, there was slack line in the second winch. In an attempt to take up the slack line, the winch operator chose to operate the doghouse winch, thereby shifting the injector head instead of taking up the slack line. The force exerted by the winch on the injector head caused the injector head to fall over, roll and come to rest against a third winch on the drill floor.

A new piece of equipment (15 tonnes) was to be installed.  A lifting yoke was prefabricated with some of the required slings.  When lifting was to commence it was found that further slings were missing.  The drawing was requested from the vendor and sent to a lifting equipment specialist to fabricate the missing slings.  While the additional slings were being fabricated the already existing slings were fitted.  And when the additional slings were installed the cargo was lifted.  Immediately the yoke broke.  No personnel were injured.  Investigation showed that the slings were incorrectly fitted.  The installation drawing was insufficiently detailed and the slings not marked, nor were they controlled. The potential of the unwanted event was injury to personnel, possibly fatal.  The situation was caused by insufficient work planning.

The IP was involved in offloading a boat. A 45ft basket was taken off the boat. The basket was to be landed by the catwalk. The basket was spotted into position in the space available. While the basket was about to be fully landed out, the injured person positioned himself between some drill pipe and the edge of the catwalk. In this position, neither the crane op nor the 2nd roustabout could see him. As the basket was fully landed out, the weight pushed the pipes several inches towards the injured person. His foot was trapped between the outer joint of pipe and the wooden dunnage. The injured person fell back into the pipedeck, and his foot came out of his boot. The IP received medical attention at the rig hospital and was subsequently medivac'd to hospital where it was confirmed he had sustained broken bones to his lower left leg.

On the 10th March a driller was working as a Banksman on guiding a cabin (heavy cargo) as it was being lowered into place on a platform. While the load was at four feet above the deck, i.e. one foot above the hand rail, it started to rotate counterclockwise. The Banksman who was standing on top of the stairway, told the crane operator to stop lowering the unit. Then he realised that the unit had swung across the top of the handrails, cutting off his escape route through the stairway. As he estimated that he could not escape below the load to reach the stairway, he sat on the handrails, and pushed himself backwards to extract his legs from the trap. He fell 4 metres backwards and hit his arm against a torque wrench lying on the deck when landing. The main injuries are fractured femur neck, deep cut on the right arm. LTI will be of 6 weeks.

An explosion occurred in a newly installed 400bbl H2O storagetank, throwing the roof 400 metres. 2 days before the incident, the tank underwent a purge using low flow sweet gas. The purge/blanket gas was then shut-in and the tank vented to a dedicated low-press flare.  Significant ambient temperature changes drew air into the tank. A high-press flare, located adjacent to the tank's dedicated low-pressure flare was flaring sweet gas when air/natural gas in the tank ignited. The flame front travelled through the tank's flare header to the tank and the roof blew off. No clear demarcation of construct and op controlled sites. Site significantly different from the standard well site set-up, but no site-specific written start-up or commissioning process. Inadequate assessment of potential encroachment of O2 when positive sweet gas press shut-in.

On August 20th 2010 the aft and forward deck cranes of an FPSO were derated in capacity by 30% and required replacement of main hoist and luff wire ropes. During the risk assessment process it was noted by the work team the rope was terminated at the main hoist drum using a •À_Chinese finger•À_ or •À_sock•À_.  This has not been seen before as a termination method by members of the work team; a sock usually being used to haul a new rope onto a crane. Typical terminations used clamps or sockets and in these instances •À_industry practice•À_ is to also retain 3 wraps on the main hoist drum when fitting the come-along. These 3 wraps included the length of the termination sock. It was considered by the work team the sock would be capable of holding the weight of the rope being replaced and to attach the come-along when 3 wraps were left on the drum.

During a routine check of a seismic vessel•À_s life boat deployment system, a chain securing the starboard life boat to a davit arm failed, putting the full weight of the lifeboat onto the other davit arm.  This caused the davit arm to fail with the result that the life boat fell from a height of approximately 6m into the sea. Initially the life boat was still attached to a painter line. The life boat was eventually recovered by a support vessel and taken under tow. The vessel had passed its annual safety equipment survey in Feb 2008.  Lifeboat falls etc were inspected at regular intervals and boats lowered every 2 weeks. The starboard life boat was last run in the water in Broome 4th March 2008.  The lifeboat falls were factory tested 19 March 2004 and fitted 06 April 2004.  The lifeboat falls were due for renewal on 06 April 2008 under SOLAS requirements, which is every 4 years.

Upon a modification to a new separator two booster/transfer pumps had been fitted to transfer pro-duced water from one separator to another.  The pumps were manually started.  Later a flange was observed releasing a spray of oil-mixed produced water from the new pipe system.  The gas detec-tors did not detect the oil, apparently due to high winds.  The pumps were stopped manually.  There was no oil released to the external environment and no personnel was hurt.  Investigation showed that the leak was caused by a broken pipe support (U-bolt).  The supporting of the pipe spool was not detailed or described in the construction material.  The running of the transfer/booster pumps was not described in a procedure.  The design of the separator weirs was not described in detail and need revisiting.  The event was caused by insufficient work planning and insufficient operational procedures.

The wellhead hydraulic control system (HPU) is located in an enclosure (approx 6' widex20'longx8'high).  Part of the control system includes a fusible loop charged with nitrogen.  The nitrogen pressure had decayed and a team investigated.  The fault was traced to a pressure relief valve on the nitrogen system.  The relief path from this valve is directly into the enclosure.  During the investigation, 2 technicians entered the enclosure and were exposed to an oxygen deficient atmosphere due to the build up of the nitrogen venting into enclosure.  Both received medical attention & have made a full recovery.  Poor design, as PSV relief placed within enclosure; plant upset caused vibration within enclosure which may have unseated PSV (set near bottom of spring range); lack of perceived threat from nitrogen, which causes rapid loss of consciousness and death,  leaking within a confined space.

During a test of the deluge system it was observed that it did not function in major parts of the platform.  Investigation showed that a new instrument tube had been incorrectly fitted to an open (not used) vent connection in a deluge skid, rendering the deluge skid inoperable.  The vent connection should have been fitted with a filter cap.  The installation drawing for the instrument tube was incomplete and did not specify the correct place of connection.  The operator had assumed the open (vent) port to be the best place for fitting the tube.  The potential of the event was that automatic release of the fire water would not have taken place in the case of a fire detected by the F&G detection system.  Consequently, in case of fire, the fire water should have been manually released, hence at best causing a delay.  The event was caused by insufficient work planning and lack of supervision.

Contractor conducting hydrotest on 6000 foot section of newly installed 30" horizontally drilled pipeline.  High pressure manifold attached to a low pressure fitting previously used for a dewatering  procedure.  The dewatering procedure was a change--MOC in place, but inadequate.  A leak occured at the fitting and 3 contractor employees approached to investigate.  When approx 30 feet from fitting, it failed at 1750 psi.  The hydrotest hose and fittings were launched & all 3 workers impacted by water and/or projectiles, resulting in multiple arm fractures; broken ribs and punctured lung and minor spleen damage; 9 broken ribs, collapsed lung and minor spleen damage. MOC processes must be detailed enough to include equipment changes and accompanied with revised procedures & drawings.  Define isolation zone for all workers and revise JSA to include detailed discussion on potential hazards.

A helicopter had been untied and left unattended on the helideck for an extended period of time while the crew was planning flight activities.  Maximum winds were less than 20 mph during planning of the days flight log. The platform received notification of extremely high winds in the vicinity and the pilot went up to properly secure the helicopter.  Prior to the pilot arriving, the wind had caught the helicopter broadside with enough force to push it against the heliport kick plate and tip it overboard into the ocean.  Wind across an 80+ mile wide line had increased to over 80 mph within a few minutes.  Other helicopter activities in the Gulf of Mexico were also impacted.  A helicopter based 80 miles away was also pushed overboard at nearly the same time during this unforecasted extreme weather event.  This incident demonstrated the need to create and follow tighter helicopter tie-down procedures.

Upon completion of works on profile in Verkhnechosk oil and gas condensate field the shooting crew of LLC TNG-Lenskoye SP-17 was in the process of handover, and the driller (born in 1960) was boarning into a multi-purpose light-armored towing vehicle, his left leg was still outside when a drilling rig mounted on catterpillar tractor TT-4 driving behind him in reverse gear hit the multi-purpose light-armored towing vehicle cabin door with a drilling rod protruding from behind to 40 cm beyond dimensions of the drilling rig on the right side. The door closed and as a result the left leg of Snegirev M.V. was squeezed between the door and the body of the multi-purpose light-armored towing vehicle.
