The casualty was rendered first aid in location. At 00:03 he was transported to Kirensk town central regional hospital by medical aviation. The diagnosis: open fracture of both bones of the keft shank with displacement.

At approximately 20:13 hrs on 15th June 2006, a gas release occurred on an offshore platform. The release was due to a loss of containment at the cover of a 3•À_•À_ Y strainer on the water outlet line from the test separator. This occurred during a well test and the vessel was operating at approx 1220 psig. The loss of containment was due to the failure of the cover plate gasket. Failure of the gasket allowed the liquid level in the vessel to be lost and gas was subsequently released from the failed joint. A substantial gas cloud was seen after the crew was alerted by one of the installation•À_s fixed gas detectors, which alarmed at the 60% LFL high level and caused the platform to change status. The crew manually initiated an Emergency Shutdown (ESD) and the facility was made safe in accordance with the emergency response procedures in use. In the course of the response, the crew manually initiated the deluge in order to disperse the gas cloud.

A drilling barge rig was running casing on a well in 7700 feet of water.  After repositioning the barge, the crew was adjusting anchor lines to "normal tension" by paying out anchor line to decrease tension on it.  The winch operator did not follow the normal procedure by utilizing the dynamic brakes to pay out line but he instead used the band brakes (operator error).  Once the line started unreeling, the band brakes could slow but could not stop the anchor line, which completely unrolled.  Several pieces of equipment were damaged as the end of the rig anchor line whipped around before being pulled into the sea.  The barge listed about 4-1/2 degrees but was stabilized at 2-1/2 degrees before being ballasted to normal position.  There were no injuries.  This incident shows the importance of fail-safe mechanical design, improved visibility, improved operator ergonomics, improved training and the need for a hazard analysis of deepwater mooring operations.

The injured person was completing a disc change to the grinder he was using. The welder then tested the grinder to see if the wheel was secured and stable. The grinder was not in, or held facing in the correct position by the welder, it was laid on its back, wheel facing upright . The welder, by depressing the On/Off switch of the grinder (the safety button which is located on top of the grinder was also depressed, due to the weight of the grinder) lying on the table, the normal operation stated by the welder, of a quick on off action to the machine, was not possible as the safety button was activated. The welder had his left hand/arm on the table, the right hand activating the on/off switch. The kick that the grinder gives when activated and the motion of the grinder swung the grinder in the direction of the welder's left arm, thus catching him across the forearm with the disc. The injured person sustained 3 stitches and was on light duies for 15 days.

There was a fire on compressor N-708. The discharge valve's cover bolts were broken, the valve cap, and the valve holding "bell" was shot to the foot-grid, the gas was flowing and ignited. The plant-fire brigade in cooperation with the govt fire-brigade started the cooling. The operators eliminated the critical sections. Additional problem occurred, when the CC2-MC2 units emergency shut down, as the gas could flow back from the flareline through a damaged valve. Decreasing the field production and started the CC2-MC2 units, the supply of the gas could be stopped, the fire was out and the unit could be cooled down. There was personal injury ( post-event psychological shock ).The plant-fire brigade in cooperation with the govt fire-brigade started the cooling. The operators eliminated the critical sections. There was a personal injury ( post-event psychological shock and a bone in his ear was broken), 155 000 m3 natural gas was burned (causing 300 tons of CO2 emission).

An explosion occurred in a power conversion building.  There was a full platform muster and all personnel were accounted for, there were no injuries.  At that time, the platform was shut in and the blowdown was initiated.  The fast responder found doors near the affected building blown out of their frames and extinguished a small fire from the doorway using a 30# fire extinguisher before reporting to muster point. All power was cut off to the building and confirmed off before fire team entered the building. Initial physical inspection by fire team (with breathing apparatus in place) found no smoldering equipment or hot spots, but some strong fumes (no smoke) so they did not immediately enter the building until ventilation could be established.  Subsequent physical inspection of the area reveals significant damage inside the building with doors blown off electrical panels, damage to transformers, external building doors blown off hinges and building's AC unit damaged as well.

At 0705 hrs, a crewmember was hit by a 5 kg CO2 fixed fire extinguisher that accidently vented and injured the person's right leg and left foot.  The fire extinguisher cylinder had been transported with the fast rescue boat (FRB) from  support vessel and was stowed in the front compartment. On the way back to the rig, the FRB crew observed  that the bottle was leaking some carbon dioxide gas. Once the FRB was fully retrieved on board the rig at 0700 hrs, the bottle was carefully placed on deck for closer inspection.  The top was frozen and by now there was no visble sign of evaporating gas. It was noticed that the pin securing the lever was slightly bent. It was decided to release the remaining gas in order to empty the bottle completly for safety reasons. Crew not involved in the procedure were asked to leave the area and two crewmembers prepared to empty the cylinder. When the the pin was released the cylinder vented uncontrollably and hit one of the crewmembers on the lower leg.

During rigging down of a tender assisted drilling rig the derrick mast was picked up off the "A" frame and rest, swung around to the NE over the platform helideck towards the tender assist barge. During the time the mast was alongside the barge, the mast started to slip and fell on the hook 4 - 5ft, indicating that the brakes were not holding. As the crane operator swung the mast over the tender, the mast began to slip continuously until the trailing end of the mast settled on the poop deck. The mast was now diagonally across the deck from starboard to port and from stern to bow, with the crown section approximately 12ft above the main deck. At this stage an investigation was made and it was deduced that the brakes had failed. The rig mechanics began to remove the brake assembly that was assumed to be the problem. When the brake was levered out of the planetary gear the main drum was released and the mast fell onto the main deck. The hook of the crane came to rest inside the mast.

Pulling out 3 •À__•À_•À_ EUE tubing was in progress at one of the Drilling Rig on 12th June 2011. The Driller sent a floor man on the man rider winch to the derrick board with a sledge hammer (approximately 10 lb) to release the elevator which was stuck. The floor man donned the man-riding safety harness with the hammer tied up with a rope to the front •À_D•À_ rings of safety harness. The hammer was placed between the straps of the harness while he ascended to the monkey board. During this activity four rig crew (3 floor man and the driller) were standing on the rotary and was installing the safety clamps on the tubing. When the floor man on the man riding winch moving closer to the elevator, the hammer slipped from the safety harness straps and fell down. Due to the impact of falling the hammer slid from the rope knot and fell from a height of approximately 90 f. One of the floor men was injured, as the hammer fell on his right shoulder. The IP sustained a fracture in the right scapula resulting in a lost workday case.

After drilling of the 16" shallow gas phase, the 13 3/8" casing got stuck 300m off the bottom; consequently, the drilling program was altered when the decision was taken to cement in place the 13 3/8" casing and followed by well head contingency procedure including cold cutting. As a consequence a 23m stick-up of 13 3/8" casing, full of mud, was standing above the wellhead which had to be cut following the successful cementing of the casing. It is supposed that thermal expansion due to heat (cement setting-up and formation temperature) caused over-pressure inside the casing. As a consequence it prematurely parted before being fully cut. The mud was projected, injuring the eyes of one of the technicians standing close by. The Weatherford Casing Over-Drive System (used to run casing) is equipped with valves which were left closed during the 19 hours prior to the cutting. These prevented mud inside casing from  venting as expected. It was the first time that cold cutting was performed with the Casing Over-drive System connected to the string.

At approximately 0515 on 8 October 2006, saturation diving work was underway to replace damaged bolts on a 26•À_•À_ flange on the export gas pipeline. The work was being conducted at a depth of approximately 100 meters and was within the 500 meter zone of the platform. The operation was to lower a 2te tools basket, 2m x 2m, fitted with tag lines and •À_•À_light sticks•À_•À_ to the seabed. The load should be lowered to a safe vertical and horizontal location and then banked to the laydown area by the divers who can see the load. The target laydown area for the load was a 4m diameter exclusion zone from the location of the divers at the flange. However the closeness of this zone coupled with the hydrodynamic sway of the 2m square basket resulted in the load landing on top of one of the two divers in the water. The load was immediately raised and the diver was recovered first to the bell then to surface and then the decompression chamber where he was examined and treated by the medic.  The diver sustained back injuries in lower lumbar area. There was no evidence of internal injury.

On 28 Oct, a CWP was issued by Network Operations allowing nitrogen purging from TFP BVS6 to TFP BVS7.  ICC #5001 was issued isolating BVS7 HOV706. The isolation was necessary to separate the nitrogen purging activity from the on-going line air drying activity from TFP-BVS7 to TFP-BVS8.  This information was made known through site check prior to the CWP issuance. On 29 Oct, the contractor started the 35 kms nitrogen purging activity venting at BVS7 HOV705 (2" vent).  The contractor Commissioning Manager realizing that the purging will take a minimum of 3 days and with the nitrogen being used depleting (40,000 M3) coupled with it a probable air mixing scenario sought clearance from the PMT Commissioning Manager to open BVS7 HOV 711 (2" vent) and the BVS7 12" vent. The latter agreed to the request. BVS HOV711 and the BVS7 12" vent was part of the air drying line that was isolated. On 1600H of 30 Oct, Network Operations, through a conversion inquiry with contractor Commissioning Manager, found out that the Isolation (Lock-Out) of BVS7 HOV706 was removed without their knowledge.

Upon completion of drilling the surface hole the crew was prepping to run 8 5/8" casing. The driller (injured party) and rig manager had agreed to have the driller go on to the floor and assist the two short service employee floorhands with the first few joints. The rig manager moved over to the console to operate the rig while running the casing. The Rig Manager positioned the elevators over the box end of the first joint of casing, which was over 40 feet in length. The Driller ensured that the elevators were rigged up and he latched the elevators around the first joint and put the latching pin in place. The rig manager, operating the console began to pick up the first joint of casing from the pipe wrangler with the elevators. When the collar/box end of the joint of casing reached approximately 39 feet up the joint the collar/box end slipped through the latched elevators, falling back to the rig floor and slid down the pipe wrangler, coming to rest on the ground at the far end of the wrangler. During this event, the Driller was struck in the head sustaining multiple injuries.

On the 25th November, 2008 at about 11:00 hours, a fit-up job and partial lamination was carried out on Line 4027 which was about 5 meters away from the drain pit. Resin and acetone chemicals were used for the job. At about 17:15 hours the lamination crew stopped working on Line 4025 and a crane was mobilized to site in order to carry out fit-up and alignment on the Tee-Spool of line 4027. As the crane position was too short for the lifting activity, and the gap was too wide for proper alignment of the pipes, the Piping Engineer stopped the work with the intention of continuing the following day. Therefore, the riggers released the crane, leaving the nylon web sling and shackles on the GRP line 4027. At about 17:45 hours, the riggers and fit-up crew left the worksite leaving only the crane operator behind. The crane operator left the site at about 17:48 hours and joined others to enter the staff bus which departed the worksite at, or about 17:53 hours. No one noticed abnormal situation up to that point in time. The generator, which was positioned few meters away from the  area, had earlier been switched off at about 17:50 hours.

On 26th Feb. 2011 approximately at 22:00 hrs., after making up the 20" casing head housing assembly to the 20" casing string the casing string was picked-up with the 20 landing joint (P/Up weight = 550,000 lbs).  Circulation was established and the lowering of the 20" casing string took place (Slack off weight = 535,000 lbs) aimed for landing the casing with the casing head housing at the landing ring.  After lowering the casing string (with housing) over a distance of 25 ft and with the casing head housing below rotary table whilst centring the casing head housing in the 30" bell nipple, the landing joint disconnected from the 20" casing string (stripped-out). The casing then fell down over the remaining distance of 35 ft. Until the casing head housing landed on the 30" landing ring.  As a result of the disconnect of the landing joint, the full volume of the 20" landing joint was released whilst still pumping. The pressure release and fluid release from the landings joint resulted in a high risk event because people were standing in the vicinity without expecting this to happen. The worst outcome from such an incident could have been a fatality.

On 18 July 2009 a High Potential Near Miss incident occurred in a company villa which could have resulted in a fatality. An electric shock to the right arm was received by the resident from the cold water tap in the villa kitchen. An immediate initial investigation by an electrician revealed that all the villa•À_s water system-associated pipes and taps were live. No electrical system safety devices had operated. Further investigation revealed that a roof water pressure pump had overheated and caused melting of an internal capacitor. This had consequently made contact with the pump chassis which had then transferred current into the steel water pipes and associated equipment throughout the house.  Physical contact with the kitchen cold water tap had been just the lightest of touches. Had the resident got hold of the tap, the outcome could have been very different. In addition to establishing the failure of the water pump in question, the electrician found that the three water pumps comprising the system as a whole were not wired through the main property electrical system but through an external supply with no earthing and no circuit breaker protection.

The incident occurred during the deployment of an acoustic array Apex mooring. A suspended load fell due to the failure of an acoustic release that was being used to lower the mooring into position. The failure occurred during the final lift for the deployment. The majority of the mooring was in the water suspended from the stopping chain. The final lift, to complete this deployment, consisted of a Current Meter, 1m chain, a float and the Oceano Acoustic Release. The Oceano release held the first part of the lift of approximately 156kg but as the full load of the mooring (approx 915kg) was taken up on the final lift, prior to the stopping chain being removed, the locking pin on the Oceano hook mechanism pulled out of the motor drive. This resulted in the suspended load falling to the deck. Part of the equipment which fell (float) struck a glancing blow to a crew members helmet. The vessel•À_s back deck sustained a 20cm x 7.5cm hole which was immediately repaired. The SWL of the Oceano release is 2.5T. There were 5 personnel involved in the back deck operations at the time of the incident. 4 of these people were in the immediate vicinity of the incident.

Bb-230 is an oil producer which was handed over to Operations after work over, waiting for installation of surface facilities and flow line tie-in to RDS-3. After hand-over, Bb-230 was equipped with a new X-Mass Tree which did not have any identification / mark-up signs.  Bb-154 (Water injector) was killed and secured for work over and the work over was completed and well handed over to Operations.  It is approximately 6 km away from Bb-230 and contractor surveyors jointly prepared a well head survey sketch and wrongly identified Bb-230 (Oil Producer) as Bb-154 (Water Injector). The survey was endorsed by Operations. The contractor started the job on the wrong site location using approved PTW. He completed the whole job of excavation, installation of concrete supports, welding & fabrication of the surface loop and finally was ready to loop tie-in to well head and flow line. Construction activities continued for 18 days without recognizing that the work execution was in the wrong location.  Later, the contractor requested another PTW for starting tie-in activities and operations foreman went to the site (Bb-230) and realized that the contractor is working on a wrongly identified well.

A serious gas leak occured on an offshore production platform following a 4th stage gas compressor trip. 16 mill Sm3/day was sent to flare through the high pressure knock-out drum. A deflector plate installed in the drum below the HP discharge gave way, eventually blocking most of the gas outlet. The pressure build-up propagated backwards through the prosess causing rupture of a glas fibre reinforced plastic pipe at the seawater return from the 3rd level gas cooler. A gas leak was detected at the coolers. The pressure in the knock-out drum had now risen to 35 barg. Design pressure was 14 barg, and the tank was tested to 23,9 barg. 15 kg of the deflector plate was extruded and moved by the gas stream into the flare pipe. The metal accelerated some 12 meters before penetrating the pipe at the first 90•À__ bend, causing a 53x42 cm hole in the flare pipe. The pipe was made of 6MO, with diameter 600 mm and wall thickness 6 mm. A large, unignited gas leak followed. Production was shut down and plant depressuration was initiated. The damage potential was severe, but there were no injuries. All process and ESD barrieres, safety systems and other barriers operated according to design specifications.

During a routine 3 year Inspection of the power boiler, the authorized Inspector (Contractor) had requested a hydrostatic test be conducted. The test pressure was established at 6205 kPa (1.5 times MAWP). The authorized Inspector communicated the required pressure to the operator using 2 different units of measure, (6205kPa and 900 psig) to ensure the test pressure was understood. The test was being conducted  in incremental steps of 300 psi for 5 minutes, 600 psi for 5 minutes and finally 900 psi for 1 hour. The test was conducted using 1 chart recorder with a calibrated ranged of 0 to 10000 kPa and a calibrated gauge with a range of 0 to 10 MPa to meet code requirements for test pressure between 25% to 67% of gauge range. The operator completed the pressure increase increments of 300, 600, and 900 reading the gauge as 3, 6, and 9. Not realizing the actual pressure increments were 3000 kPa, 6000 kPa, and 9000 kPa. The test was held for 1 hour successfully. However, ASME Section I boiler construction codes states that at no time can a hydro test pressure exceed 6% of test pressure or exceed 90% of material yield strength. Actual test pressure used was over 2 times the MAWP which over pressured the boiler.
